div.p: MAR-PLOT; Or The Second Part of The BUSIE-BODY. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Drury-Lane, BY Her MAJESTY's Servants.
LONDON: Printed for Jacob Tonſon at Shakeſpear's Head over-againſt Catherine-ſtreet in the Strand. 1711.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE HENRY BENTINCK, EARL of Portland, Viſcount Woodſtock, Baron of Cirenceſter, Captain of Her Majeſty's Firſt Troop of Guards, &c.
div.p:
WOmen, and Men like Women, naturally fly to the Brave for Protection. This Pretence Mar-plot and I have for Addreſſing to your LORDSHIP. We know it is the peculiar Diſtinction of Noble Minds, that they are ready to receive under their
Care the Diſtreſs'd, though they have no other Merit, than that they beſeech their Patronage.

When I ſay this, my LORD, I wou'd not be underſtood to conceal, that my Play has been very kindly receiv'd; but we Women overlook all Praiſe, but from thoſe Perſons whoſe Approbation we moſt eſteem. We are apt to be carry'd away from Admirers to thoſe we Admire: And this Comedy prefers the Honour of being thrown at Your Feet, to the Applauſe of an Audience. It is the Misfortune of our Sex, that we are deterr'd from the Advantages of a Learned Education: But as our Expreſſions are Artleſs, our Sentiments are leſs Diſguis'd. Had I, my LORD, the Skill of a Writer, I ſhou'd here record your Noble Father's Zeal for his Royal Maſter, and celebrate that Care and Fidelity which preſerv'd the Life of Our Deliverer: But, inſtead of mentioning this Obligation, which my late Lord Portland laid on every Man in England, I confine my ſelf to what we owe Him for being your Father.

That Your LORDSHIP may long bleſs the World with the ſame Virtues which You have ſhown in the Entrance You have made on the buſie Stage of it, and long enjoy the Advantages of an Affluent Fortune, Graceful Perſon, and Generous Mind, is the ardent Prayer of,

closer.signed: Your Lordſhip's moſt Devoted, moſt Obedient, Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENTLIVRE.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: THE Men of Wit do now their Brains fatigue
So much with Politicks and State-Intrigue!
That there's not one Male-Poet of the Age
Will condeſcend to labour for the Stage.
Therefore our Author, tho' no Rules ſhe knows,
What Nature prompts, with Artleſs Hand beſtows:
You'll ſee the Subject for the Genius fit,
A Buſie-Body, drawn by Female Wit,
Still on the Hunt to know of others Wooing,
Eternally employ'd, and nothing doing!
Into dear Secrets anxiouſly they preſs,
Deſtroying, even where they wiſh Succeſs!
The ſcanty Age all better Fare denies,
And no new Characters the Town ſupplies.
Some Years ago Wit had a larger Field,
And every Room cou'd freſh Stage-Coxcombs yield;
But long has been all Humorous Folly croſt,
All Fool in empty Politician's loſt.
Scowrers, and Rakes, and Debauchees are o'er,
Beaux are extinct, and Bullies are no more.
Therefore in Scarcity of home-bred Tools,
Your Treat to Night's compos'd of Foreign Fools;
And tho' our Mar-plot has been ſhown before,
The Fool may differ, on a different Shore—
For once, then, break old Cuſtom; be not o'er-nice,
But let the ſelf-ſame Woman pleaſe you Twice.

div.stage: The SCENE the Terriera de Paſſa in Lisbon.

div.head: SCENE I.

head.hi: SCENE, The Terriera de Paſſa in Lisbon.

div.stage: Enter Don Lopez, and Don Perriera.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: WHY Brother, you are diſtracted; how often have you fill'd my Brain with theſe Chymera's? Why ſhould I murder my Wife without a Cauſe?

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: A Cauſe! Do's a Cuckold want a Cauſe?

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: Look ye, Senior, keep that Word Cuckold between your Teeth, till you can prove me ſuch, or by St. Anthony you ſhall feel what Mettle my Spado is made of. [Laying his Hand to his Sword.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Name your Spado again, and I'll ſhake thee into Duſt, thou feeble Dotard. Your Spado! employ it againſt the Man that robs you of your Honour, and not againſt him that would preſerve it. I ſay, My Siſter, your Wife, is a Strumpet, the Strumpet of a damn'd Heretick: I ſaw the Looks, nay the Signs, ſhe gave ſome of the Engliſh Officers, as ſhe came from Church this Morning.

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: Engliſh Officers!

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p:
Engliſh I'm ſure they were, I can't ſwear they were all Officers, nor cou'd I perceive which ſhe ſign'd to, or he ſhou'd not live to meet her Wiſhes—Now if you don't like the Name of Cuckold, find another for the Husband of a Whore, if you can—For my part I know of none; but this I know, if you won't puniſh her as a Wife, I will as a Siſter; ſhe ſhall not ſtain
the Honour of my Houſe this way; ſhe injur'd it too much in marrying you. I ſhall purſue my own Method, and ſo Farewell. [Going.

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: So, there's the Bleſſing of matching into an honourable Family: Now muſt I bear all Affronts patiently, becauſe I'm but a Merchant, forſooth—Oh, give me any Curſe but this—Pray, Senior, give me leave to ſpeak one Word with you: I am convinc'd of my too much Indulgence for this very Cockatrice, and there remains nothing to quicken my Revenge, but certain Demonſtration.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Certain Demonſtration! Muſt you have Ocular Proof? Muſt your Coward Heart be animated with the Sight? A Curſe of your Equivocations—

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: No, any other Senſe will ſerve; let me hear 'em, feel 'em, nay, ſmell 'em; and ſure Cuckoldom is ſo rank a Scent, that, tho' I liv'd in England, where they ſcarce breathe any other Air, I cou'd diſtinguiſh it.

sp.speaker: D. Lop.
sp.p: Now you talk like a Portugueſe; keep up this Paſſion, and ſecure the Honour of your Houſe and mine, and deſerve the Alliance of my Blood, it ſhall be my Care to fix them.

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: And when they are ſo, mine to execute.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Colonel Ravelin!

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Charles Gripe! honeſt Charles, how doſt thou do, Boy? Why, what brought thee to Lisbon?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Part of the Cauſe that brought you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: What? art thou in the Army?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No, Colonel, I leave Honour to you, Intereſt brought me.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: They are Twin-Brothers, Charles; if Intereſt did not drive, Honour wou'd come ſlowly on: Art thou turn'd Merchant then?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No, faith, not I; but it pleas'd Heav'n to take my Wife's Father out of the way, who left me Executor, and his Concerns here oblig'd me to take this Voyage.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: So then, old Sir, jealous Traffick is dead at laſt. How long do you intend to ſtay?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Longer than I expected when I embark'd: I came away in ſuch a Hurry, the Ship ſailing ſooner than I thought ſhe
wou'd, I forgot to put up ſome Papers, without which I can't adjuſt my Accounts with ſome Merchants here; I have writ to my Wife to ſend them.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: That was very unlucky; prithee, how doſt thou ſpend thy Time?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why very inſipidly: How do you paſs yours? What Company have you here?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: All ſorts; the Women, I'll ſay that for 'em, are kind enough, and won't put you to the Expence of Swearing and Lying to gain them; but a Man is as ſafe in an Engagement, as in their Arms; Fortune is the kind Friend in both the Onſets: But I have got acquainted in a French Family, which are not altogether ſo dangerous one way, but much more ſo another.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ay! how's that, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Why, I'm fearful of dwindling into an honourable Amour there.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Exert your Gallantry, gain your Point once, and thoſe Fears will vaniſh. The French Ladies are eaſie of Acceſs.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Right, the French Gayety reſembles the Engliſh Complaiſance, yet they have always a Reſerve to daſh your Expectations, and when you think your ſelf in a manner Maſter of their Cover'd-way, they ſpring a Mine of Coquetry, and blow you up at once.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Colonel? Why then give me the Lisbon Dames, that ſurrender to the Bold and Brave: He deſerves not a Woman, that would not run ſome Hazard, provided ſhe be kind.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Some are of Opinion, that the jilting Fair gives the ſureſt Blow, and Sucklin ſays, 'Tis Expectation makes the Bleſſing dear. This French Woman has found the way to unite my jarring Inclinations, and tune 'em to the pitch of Conſtancy, and I am very apprehenſive of becoming that tame Monſter, call'd a Husband. Ah! I find I am caught, for I can name that terrible Word without ſtarting.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I ſhall have you in my Claſs: Sure the Lady that can make ſuch an entire Conqueſt over your Heart muſt be a Perſon of extraordinary Parts, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p:
Yes, faith, her Ladyſhip has very extraordinary Parts; ſhe's airy to Affectation, and changeable as the Wind: She has
Tongue enough for a Lawyer, but as hard to be underſtood as an Apothecary: She begins as many Stories as a Romance, and ends them as intricately, or, to ſpeak more properly, ſeldom ends them at all: She's as whimſical as a Projector, as obſtinate as a Phyſician, and as faithful as the Monarch of her Country.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Admirable Qualities for a Wife; and can you forſake the whole Sex for this Woman?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Humph! that I won't ſwear; but I find I can't forſake her for the whole Sex: To be plain with you, I have try'd the Strength of Variety, and at this time am in proſpect of the Favour from as fine a Woman as any in Lisbon; yet this Medly of Womankind triumphs over all, and in the midſt of my Raptures I murmur Joneton.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But may I not ſee this wondrous Engineer, who can countermine her whole Sex, and blow up the Magazine of your Affections, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You ſhall, but you muſt give me your Honour not to rival me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Deſcription you have given, Colonel, ſecures you from that Fear; beſides, you know I am marry'd, neither am I deſtitute of a Miſtreſs, tho' in a ſtrange Place. I this Morning was a aſſur'd, by a Sign from a Lady's Hankerchief, that my Wants ſhou'd be ſupply'd upon Occaſion. I did not rightly underſtand her, till the good old Duena explain'd her Meaning; and this Night I ſhall be happy in her Arms.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You are a Stranger to theſe Affairs Charles, take heed, proceed with caution, for the Women here are as warm in their Revenge as in their Inclinations, bare Suſpicion juſtifies Murder; if you manage your Intreague ſo cloſely to eſcape the Husband and Relations, 'tis odds but your Miſtreſs finds ſome pretence to employ her Bravoes, Fellows that will diſpatch a dozen Men for a Moydre.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
I go well arm'd, underſtand the Language, and will not eaſily fall a Victime, but reſolve to ſee the event of this Intreague; the old Matron told me that the Lady was young and beautiful, her Husband a Merchant, rich, covetous, old, and ugly; that ſhe hated him worſe than Penance, and lov'd me better than her Prayers; ſhall I be ſuch a Poultroon to decline a Lady's Summons? No, for the honour of Britain, it ſhall never be ſaid an Engliſhman fled either from the Wars of Mars, or
Venus; let her bring me on, if I diſcharge not my ſelf with Honour, and make my Retreat ſecure, may I forfeit the Embraces of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Well ſaid Charles, in my Conſcience you married Men encroach too much upon our Prerogative methinks; you who purchaſe pleaſure by way of Annuity, ſhould leave us Batchellours the liberty of the Freehold.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Ground we courſe in, is never the worſe for your Uſe.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: No, 'tis ſometimes the better; there's many a Wife lies Fallow, and many a good Eſtate wou'd want an Heir, if it were not for us young Fellows, eſpecially Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I think you ought to make Proviſion for the Recruits you raiſe, as much as for your Widows, they are far more Numerous.
sp.stage: [A noiſe of claſhing of Swords, and Murder cry'd within.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ha! What noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: 'Tis Mar-plot's Voice, his damn'd Curioſity has brought him into ſome Miſchief, I'll lay my Life on't.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: The Devil's in that Fellow; what made you bring him with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Murder, murder, [Mar. running purſued by two Bravoes. Ah Charles, help me dear Charles, for Heav'ns ſake.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A Curſe on your Paper Skull, what have you been doing now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nothing at all, as I hope to be ſaved; only I had a mind to ſee where that Lady liv'd that ſhook her Handkerchief at you, and out of no other deſign than to inform you, I proteſt, Charles, when immediately theſe two Scoundrels came ſlap upon me, I know no more for what than the Child that's unborn; but I'm ſure I ſhall feel their blows this Month, pox take 'em.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: For what? Why you took the only method in the World to have your Guts let out: Ha, ha! watch a Woman in Lisbon! Hark you young Gentleman, ſuppreſs that natural Curioſity of diving into other Peoples Affairs, or never hope to ſee old England again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wiſh I were ſafe in it, Colonel Ravelin! The duce take me if I ſaw you before, my Senſes was all in ſuch a hurry, with theſe unconſcionable Villains, that—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That you over-look'd your Friends, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have ſaid it Charles, but I hope the Colonel will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: To be plain with you, Mr. Mar-plot, I ſhall take theſe kind of Over-ſights for particular Favours, if you don't ſhake off that Temper of yours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Piſh, prethee Colonel don't put on thoſe grave Airs, why what harm is there in't?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: There's ill Manners in't, I'm ſure, and have a care you han't your Bones broke for it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Look ye Mar-plot, you muſt either reſolve to quit this inquiſitive Humour, or forfeit my Acquaintance,

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: A Man may be ruin'd by your fooliſh Quarrels.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, Colonel, I never quarrel'd with any Man, out of deſign to hurt him in my Life: Charles can witneſs for me, that I hate fighting.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: So can every Body elſe that knows you; I wiſh you hated Impertinence as much, for the good of Society.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, you of all Men living have the leaſt reaſon to complain; I have run the hazard of my Life many a time for you, and in my Conſcience I believe I ſhall fall your Martyr one time or another.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Your own you mean, you'll certainly be Canoniz'd by all the Buſie-body's about Town.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is this all the thanks I get for my Friendſhip? Well Charles, well, you ſhall ſee I can prefer Safety, and ſacrifice my Curioſity too, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: That's the way to oblige your Friends, Mr. Mar-plot, never deſire to know more than they are willing to tell you, readily comply with a reaſonable Demand, and never meddle with any body's Buſineſs but your own, this will render you agreeable to all Companies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay! But that will make all Companies very diſagreeable to me. (Aſide.) But Colonel, is there nothing due from one Friend to another? One ought to be let into the boſom Secrets of a Friend.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Not always, for there are ſome Secrets of ſuch a Nature that will not admit of that Freedom; for Example, ſuppoſe your Friend had an Affair with another Man's Wife, or Daughter, where's the advantage of your knowing it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why I wou'd watch the Husband or Father in the mean time, prevent his being ſurpriz'd, and perhaps ſave his Life.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But how wou'd you ſave his Honour? A Man of Honour muſt have no Confidents in thoſe Caſes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then hang Honour, I ſay, 'tis good for nothing but to ſpoil Converſation. Shall I beg a pinch of your Snuff, Colonel?

div.stage: Enter Colonel Ravelin's Servant with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Meſſenger ſtays for your Anſwer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Letter! Wou'd I were a Fly now, that I might ſwop down upon the Paper, and read it before his Face: Lord, Lord, what wou'd I give for an univerſal Knowledge? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Tell the Meſſenger I'll obſerve Orders to a ſecond

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Orders! Why, what have you Orders to march, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: From this place I have, Sir. Charles, I'd be glad to drink a Bottle with you and Mr. Mar-plot in the Evening at my Lodgings: There's the Directions.
sp.stage: [Tears the Superſcription of a Letter, and gives Charles.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll wait on you home Colonel, that I may know the Houſe again exactly.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, I'm not going home perhaps. Charles, I'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'll do my ſelf the honour to wait on you; adieu.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Perhaps! but perhaps I won't believe you: He has a world of Manners to a Gentleman in a ſtrange Place, I'll be ſworn; ha! Charles's gone, nay, then I have a rare opportunity, egad he has forgot his Snuff-Box, an excellent Excuſe to follow him; the Devil take his Letter for me, it has given me the Cholick.

head.hi: SCENE, A Chamber in Don Perriera's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Are you ſure the Engliſhman will come? What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He •• ſwer'd me in Tranſport, I warrant him a Man every inch of him Come, Seniora? Yes, yes, he'll come, tho' a thouſand Dangers threatned him; theſe Engliſhmen are brave Fellows, if they were not Hereticks.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: If he has but the Faith of a Lover, no matter for his Religion Margaritta; but what came of the buſie Fellow that watch'd us? Did you obey my Orders?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes marry did I, and the Bravo's aſſur'd me they had taught him to look another way for the future.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: They diſpatch'd him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, he was reſcu'd, upon the Terriera de Paſſa.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ill Fate; he did not ſee where I enter'd.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no, Madam, you are ſafe; huſh, here's my Maſter Don Perriera.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Then there's my Jaylor: This Engliſhman runs in my Head ſo much, that methinks I hate the Sight of my Husband.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: So, you have been at Church to Day, my Dear, have you not?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Yes, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: And who did you ſee there, Wife?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Do you think I paſs my Time in Obſervation at Church, my Dear? I hope I have other Buſineſs to do there.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: And you are baſely bely'd, if you have not other Buſineſs to do elſewhere too, Wife.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What do you mean, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Nay, ask your Brother Don Lopez, who will have it that you ſend your Eyes a m • rroding for Engliſh Forage; my Dear, have a care of an Ambuſcade; for the whole Artillery of his Senſes are drawn down upon you, and Jealouſie leads the Force of his Invention; and though I love you, Wife, yet if his Spies bring certain Intellige • ce of your holding Correſpondence with thoſe Heretick Dogs, the Engliſh Officers, I ſhall infallibly treat you like a Traitreſs to your Lord and Husband.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ha! I fear I'm betray'd. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: My Lady a Traitreſs to her Lord and Husband! Don Lopez is a Traitor to his own Fleſh and Blood for ſaying ſo, by my Virginity—

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Away, away; that's ſo ſtale an Oath, 'twill not be credited.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p:
The Accuſation's falſe, I do not know one Engliſh Officer in Lisbon, by this ſacred Sign; [croſſes her Thumb and Finger, and kiſſes it.] For my Duena aſſures me my Lover is no
Officer; ſo far I'm not forſworn. [Aſide.] I thought, my Dear had promis'd me never more to mind the Inſinuations of that cruel Brother; his Prejudice is founded on our Marriage, his proud imperious Temper ſcorns your Alliance, and racks his Soul to find a Cauſe to ruin you: And muſt it be by blaſting of my Fame? Will not my Life ſuffice? And dares he not employ his own Hand? But wou'd he make you guilty of my Murther? oh barbarous inhumane Thought!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Cruel Don Lopez, now do I wiſh I may die a Maid; a terrible Wiſh, were I not out of Danger of the Curſe falling upon me; if I believe my Lady ever thought of any Man but your ſelf, Senior. Poor Creature, I'm ſure her Heart is full of Fears about you when you are abſent.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Ay, leſt I ſhou'd come back before ſhe'd have me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He is the Devil of a Gueſſer. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Unkindly urg'd, Deary; I'm ſure, by my own Conſent, I wou'd never have you—

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: In your Sight.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The Man is certainly a Witch. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Out of my ſight, I meant, Deary.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: That wou'd be as bad on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: For my part, Deary, I'm never happier than when thou art in my Arms, and cou'd be content to have thee always there.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhou'd have a fine Life truly, to be always in your Arms.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Look ye there now, the Dog in the Manger.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me ſay, my Dear, to convince you of my Love?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Look ye, Wife, 'tis no matter what you ſay, do but take care what you do: No regaling your Pallate with Foreign Diſhes, they are very dangerous. Take my Word for't, you'll live longer upon your own Food, and with leſs Danger of your Health.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, if Diſeaſes are prevented by dry Meats, he's in the right on't. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: I know not what you'd have me ſay, my Dear; but if you think me falſe, confine me to my Chamber, or ſend me to a Monaſtery. Grant, Heav'n, he do's not take me at my Word. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I wou'd not give a Cruſada for my Place, if he ſhou'd; a cloyſter'd Miſtreſs brings no Griſe to the Servant's Mill. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Sure Don Lopez do's belye her; I always found her thus pliable, kind, and modeſt; however, I'll watch her narrowly. In the mean time, to take off her Suſpicion, I'll ſeem to believe her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: So, all's right once more, I ſee by that Ogle of his. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Come, my Love, dry thy Eyes; I am not jealous, nor ſhall thy Brother make me ſo; I'll be an Engliſhman to thee. Come, buſs thy own Husband then, do Deary.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: That Buſs ſecures me a Moydre before I ſleep, for the Engliſh are the moſt generous Men living in their Love Affairs. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: And won't you be jealous of me no more indeed, and indeed, nor let that naughty Brother vex you, till you fright me out of my Wits again? Will you promiſe me that?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and indeed, I will, you little coaxing Thief you. By St. Anthony, thou doſt look wondrous handſome methinks. Od! if I were not to meet ſome Merchants about Buſineſs, thou ſhould'ſt to Bed this Moment.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: To Bed quotha? I had rather thou wert in thy Grave. [Aſide.] What? then are you going to leave me, my Jewel?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: But for two or three Hours, my Dear; and then I will ſo buſs it, and love it, and hug it, and ſqueeze it.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ah! the very Apprehenſion makes me ſick. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: What makes my Dear ſick?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: The Duce take his Ears—The Apprehenſion of loſing my dear, little, old Man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well turn'd. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt quickly have me again, my Jewel.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Too ſoon, I dare ſwear. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: By Deary, go make much of thy ſelf till I come back. Here, Seniora Margaritta, take care of your Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes, Senior, a better Care than you think for. Come, Madam, now prepare to receive the charming Engliſhman.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: I think I had better let it alone; do you conſider the Hazard which I run?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hazard! Are you born in Portugal, and talk of Hazard? Why, there is not a Woman in Lisbon that wou'd not run twice as much for ſuch a Fellow—Do you conſider the Difference between him and your old Husband?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Yes, and what I muſt ſuffer too, if I am caught.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, nay, if Fear throws ſo many Bug-bears in your way, follow your own Fancy: I'm like to make a fine Penny on't truly—Pray ſend me of no more Fool's Errands; I'll carry no more Challenges, if you do not mean to engage: I trifle my Time away ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Nay, don't be angry, Marget; 'tis not but that I have as much Inclination for that handſome Man as ever, were I ſure not to be diſcover'd, I ſhou'd not alter my Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: That ſhall be my Care, I warrant you, Madam; he comes in by a Rope-Ladder at your Cloſet-window, by which he may return with Secrecy and Expedition upon the leaſt Surprize.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: My Cloſet-window looks upon the River, how can he come that way?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: By a Boat, that ſhall wait to receive him again.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Let him come then.

l.hi: When Inclination pleads, Fears quickly fly,
And powerful Love can Reaſon's Force defy.

head.hi: SCENE changes to Colonel Ravelin's Lodgings.

div.stage: The Colonel looking on his Watch.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: 'Tis within two Minutes of the Time; I muſt be punctual; for Women here forgive not the leaſt Omiſſion. Let me ſee, is my Trap-door unbolted? Not yet?
sp.stage: [Goes to the Chimney, and ſeems to pull at a Trap-door.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's a Gentleman to wait on you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I'll ſee no body: Did not I tell you ſo, Block-head?
sp.stage: [Gives him a Box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis only I, Colonel; don't be angry, you forgot your Snuff-box, and I thought you wou'd want it, ſo I brought it you, that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you need not have given your ſelf the Trouble.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think it no Trouble, upon my Soul, Sir. Ad! you have very pretty Lodgings here, Colonel: What a very fine Collection of Pictures you have got? Pray who is this at length, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I can't tell indeed, Sir; they belong to the Houſe. Pox take this Coxcomb. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ho, do they ſo? Pray what do you give a Week for theſe Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Prithee ask me no Queſtions; I don't know, I have forgot. Ha! the Door unbolts, which way ſhall I get rid of this Puppy? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hey-day! forgot! that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, I perceive it is impoſſible for me to anſwer all the Queſtions you may poſſibly ask at this time; but in the Evening I promiſe to ſolve all your Interrogatories.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Colonel, if I am troubleſome, I'll be gone—This Uneaſineſs has a Meaning. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You'll oblige me in ſo doing, Mr. Mar-plot; for I have a Viſit to make this Moment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is it to Man or Woman, Colonel? Come hang it, you may tell me that.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Why then, it is to a Lady: Now I hope you'll leave me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, ay, with all my Heart; but I may go with you to the Door, may I not?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Go to the Devil, Sir. Death, how ſhall I ſhift him off? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How ſnappiſh he is—how the duce ſhall I manage to find out this Intrigue? [Aſide.] Well, well, don't be angry Colonel: I'll leave you below Stairs,

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Confound his Impertinence. Death Sir, ſuppoſe I don't go down Stairs, how then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How then? Why how then do you intend to make your Viſit, Colonel? You don't go out at the Window, do you?

sp.speaker: Rav
sp.p: No more of your Impertinence, Sir, but be gone, or I ſhall fling you out at Window.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if you be ſo Cholerick, your humble Servant Egad I'll ſecure the Key, I will know the bottom of this, if I die for't.
sp.stage: [Snatches the Key of the Door, and puts it in his Pocket, and Exits. The Colonel ſlaps the Door after him, then runs to the Trap-door, pulls it up and deſcends, and pulls it down after him.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: This is the moſt intolerable Dog I ever ſaw: Pox take him, there's half a minute claps'd.
sp.stage: [Mar-plot opens the Door ſoftly and peeps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Egad he's not come out yet, what is he a doing? Ha! I don't ſee him—nor hear him neither—od, I'll venture in—upon my Soul here's no Body: Why ſure he deals with the Devil—here's no Door but this that I can ſee—Is there any way out at Window?—No, faith, that's impoſſible, they have all Iron Bars.—What can be become of him? Oh! I have it now, before George he's gone up the Chimney, for there is no other Paſſage—it muſt be ſo, [Peeps up the Chimney] Egad the Chimney is large, and eaſy enough to mount, now have I a ſtrong inclination to follow him—troth and I will too—ſure the greateſt pleaſure in this World, l •… s in diſcovering what other People take ſuch pains to conceal—now they may call me impertinent Block head—inquiſitive Fool—and ill-bred Puppy—and what they pleaſe, but I'd not quit the pleaſure of knowing this Secret, for the fineſt breeding in France.—I'm afraid I ſhall ſpoil my Coat—rot him, what a curſed, dirty Contrivance has he found out; hold, well thought on—I'll, I'll, turn the wrong ſide outwards—Ay, that will do, [Turns his Coat] ſo now for the Art of Chimney Sweeping; egad Colonel, in ſpight of all your caution, ten to one but I know your haunts; Lord how I ſhall laugh at Night, when we meet, how I will Joak upon him. Ha, ha, ha.
sp.stage: [Goes into the Chimney, and the Scene ſhuts.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: COme, Courage, Senior Engliſe, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I hope you have a better Opinion of my Country, Seniora, than to think me afraid; but where is the Lady? the beautiful young Lady, which you told me off, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She's forth-coming, Sir—So, ſee what it is to be ſtricken in years now, he looks over me, as if I were a thing of his own Species. Well Senior, I aſſure you I have done you no ſmall ſervice with my Lady, poor young thing, ſhe had ſo many ſcruples, but I told her a thouſand things in your Favour: Seniora ſaid I, the Cavalier is a fine Cavalier, he is—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, if this old Woman's Clack ſets a going, there will be no end—I underſtand you Senior, pray give me leave to thank you; and to engage you more heartily in my Intereſt, be pleas'd to accept this Token of my Eſteem.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah Seniora, you Engliſh have excellent faculties to pleaſe us Women; I'll ſwear they have exceeding good natural Parts, and readily conceive our Meaning, [Aſide.] I'll acquaint my Lady that you are here, Senior.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Prethee do—So, I am enter'd, but how I ſhall come off, I am not able to determine: If inſtead of a Lady, there ſhou'd come an old ſurly Dog, with half a dozen Bravoes at his back, it would give a ſtrange turn to my Inclinations; how fooliſhly a Man muſt look upon ſuch an Occaſion; egad ſuppoſe ſome Body ſhould be doing me the ſame favour in England now with my Wife, cou'd I be angry? No faith; if a Man is born to be a Cuckold 'tis none of his Wife's fault, and therefore Senior, Don, what de call 'em, by your leave, if your Wife be handſome.

Ha! here ſhe comes; a thouſand Darts iſſue from her Eyes—What a Forehead's there? Her Lips exceed the redneſs of the Coral—'tis ſure the Queen of Love—Ay, 'tis ſhe, thoſe dimples in her Cheeks are Cupid's bathing Tubs, and that ſnowy
Boſome the Plain he keeps his Revels on—Seniora [Going towards her.] the duce take me if I can ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurpriz'd, Senior.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Who can look on ſuch amazing Brighneſs without aſtoniſhment of Senſe? Semele, when Jove approach'd her in all his Glory, had not more cauſe to be ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: You begin as if we had years to waſte in Courtſhip, Senior, pray deſcend from your high-flown Raptures, the Gods are no Example, let us talk like Mortals.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But are you ſure, Madam, that you are Mortal?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: I'm afraid he'll find me ſo, he's a charming handſome Fellow. [Aſide.] By your Diſtance one wou'd imagine that you took me for a Shadow, but you may venture to approach, I am Fleſh and Blood, I ſhan't vaniſh. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Say you ſo Madam? Why then have at you, I was never afraid of Fleſh and Blood in my Life—Ha! The Devil! a Dagger!
sp.stage: [Runs to catch her in his Arms, ſhe holds up a Dagger, he ſtarts back.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; what, do you ſtart at a Dagger, Senior?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes, in a Female Hand, thoſe Limbs were made for ſofter Uſes; and we Britains are not wont to ſee our Ladies arm'd with Steel: Loves Combats are fought with Kiſſes, in my Country, I know not what his Laws are here.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: The Engagements are the ſame, only a little difference in the Preparation; a Wound in the Reputation of an Engliſh Woman, they ſay, only lets in Allimony, but with us it lets out Life: And therefore, tho' we proceed with caution, a Lover ought to think us ſincere, when we run ſuch hazards to receive him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But to what end is the Dagger, Madam; is it to diſpatch your Lover by way of keeping the Secret—faith he'll have but ſmall ſtomach to Eat, that knows he muſt Die as ſoon as he has Din'd.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: No Senior, by this I wou'd imprint in your Mind the danger which we are both expos'd to, if we are not both diſcreet; Favours in Portugal muſt not be boaſted off.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Nor any where elſe, Madam; a Man of Honour ſcorns ſo poor a piece of Treachery; he that owns he ever had a Favour,
proclaims himſelf both lewd and fooliſh, but he that points the Woman out is a Villain, and ought to have that Dagger in his Heart.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Nobly ſaid. [Throws away the Dagger.] That Sentence has diſarm'd and left me at your Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then thus I ſeize, and thus I will revenge the Arts you took to fright me. Ha! her Kiſſes would warm the Dead, I'm all Extacy. I fancy the next Room is more private Madam, and I have a ſecret to impart of mighty Conſequence, therefore prethee let's withdraw.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Oh happy Engliſh Women, that have ſuch Men as theſe plenty. Oh my Heart, I find I have not power to deny him—Open that Door, Margaritta.
sp.stage: [Opens the Door, Marplot flops down the Chimney, the Women ſhriek, Charles draws his Sword, Mar-plot roars out, the Women run off.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: So, ſo, they underſtand one another,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, Zounds I have broke my Leg.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah! Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Mona Per.
sp.p: Ah! Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Mar-plot! The Devil break your Neck, which way got you hither? I have a good mind to ſtick you, you Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: falls on his Knees.] Ah, dear Charles, is it you? Oh forgive me for Heav'ns ſake, this was pure Accident, as I hope to be ſav'd, the Devil take me if I dreamt of finding you.
Within.] Thieves! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Death, they'll raiſe the Houſe, and I ſhall be taken for a Thief, the Women will ſwear they know nothing of me, I warrant 'em. Rogue, Dog, Poultroon.
sp.stage: [Beats Mar-plot, and Exits into the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, good Charles——Oh, oh, oh, what ſhall I do? Oh Lord, oh Lord, dear Charles take me out with you [Exit after Charles, and returns.] Oh, woe's me that ever I was born, he is leapt into the River; was there ever ſuch an unfortunate Dog as I am, to be in queſt of one, and tumble upon t'other? tho' if I cou'd but get ſafe out, and Charles ſcape with Life, the Accident wou'd not diſpleaſe me neither, but if Charles be drown'd, I ſhall hang my ſelf, that's certain.
Within.] Thieves, Thieves! Lorenzo, Pedro Sancho; where are you all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh frightful! the whole Houſe is up in Arms, which way ſhall I eſcape? Ah! methinks I feel a Spado thro' my Guts already: Egad, there is no way but up the Chimney again.

div.stage: Enter Don Perriera and his Wife; Margaritta, and other Servants arm'd.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Whre are theſe Rogues, my Dear? I'll ſwinge 'em. How many was there?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: We ſaw ten at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Yes indeed did we—with Piſtols and Spadoes, and Heav'n knows what. Is my Lover got off clear? [Aſide to Marg.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Without Diſpute, for the Ladder is gone.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What cou'd that Fellow be? I wiſh he was no Spy from my Brother Don Lopez. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Why where are they all? And which way got they in?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: They all came down the Chimney, Senior.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Down the Chimney? here, Raſcal, ſearch the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Take heed, Lorenza, and kill the firſt you light on—The Dead can diſcover nothing. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Here's one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Take him alive, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ah! then all will out, and I'm ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: How now, Sir? What are you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I can't tell what I am, Sir, not I.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: 'Tis an Engliſhman, and can't belong to Don Lopez. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Can't you ſo, Sir? Death! how came you here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, I know as little of that too, for my part; what will become of me? Theſe Fellows have damn'd Murdering Faces. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Where are the reſt of your Gang, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, Heav'n knows; wou'd I were with them.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Zounds, Sirrah, anſwer without theſe Equivocations, or, by St. Anthony, I'll have you wrack'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah! the Devil take your Popiſh Saints; for they are always bloody-minded: I can't think of any tolerable Lye to ſave my Life now. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak, I ſay? Where are the other Nine? Here was Ten of you juſt now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ten! As I hope for Mercy from your Hands, Sir, I ſaw but one; and how he came here, may I be caſtrated if I know. 'Tis true, he is a Friend of mine, but I won't anſwer for his Virtue for all that, when there is a handſome Woman in the caſe; for Beauty is a Temptation, you know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Undone! this Fellow knew the other. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: How's this? a handſome Woman—I wiſh my Wife has not a Hand in the Plot. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: [Aſide to Mar-plot.] Recal what you have ſaid; not one Word more of the Man you ſaw here, as you hope to live two Hours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, wretched Mar-plot, what will become of thee? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Did you not tell me you ſaw ten arm'd Men come down the Chimney, Wife?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: For my part I was ſo frighted, my Dear, that I durſt have ſworn I ſaw twenty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ay, ſo did I too, Senior; for People in a Fright ſee double.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n, ſome body had no Deſign to be double. [Aſide.] Where is this Friend of your's, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Friend, Sir?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Why him you ſaid you ſaw here juſt now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah! that was all a Miſtake, Sir; I did not know what I ſaid, Sir, nor, I believe, did not know what I meant, and I'm ſure I did not neither, except I meant my ſelf, Sir. Nay, now I think on't, I did mean my ſelf, Sir—Oh Lord, oh Lord, which way ſhall I come off? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Don't ſtammer ſo, Raſcal; I ſhall have no Mercy on you preſently——Did you not ſay you ſaw a Friend of yours here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why if I did, Sir, I meant my ſelf; and there needs no Logick to prove a Man's beſt Friend is himſelf, tho' I am ſure I am my own worſt Foe. Oh, I ſhall ſwoond away with the Fright. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: You ſaid, you knew not how he came here neither.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My ſelf again, Sir; for as I hope to get ſafe out, I had no more Deſign to come into your Houſe, than I had to eat it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: And dare not you ſwear for your own Virtue neither 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No really, Sir, no Man knows his own Strength; and I confeſs ingenuouſly, Sir, that a pretty Woman has Power to diſſolve my Reſolutions of Virtue at any time.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? Why then there are things to be us'd to preſerve Virtue, which I'll take care to adminiſter I'll engage you ſhall attempt no Man's Wife for the future. Here, bind his Hands.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis a handſome Young-Man, and no Fool. I wiſh I cou'd tell how to ſave him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, dear Sir, what do you mean? I deſign upon a Man's Wife! Upon my Soul, Sir, I never had any ſuch damnable Deſign in my Days, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Sirrah, Sirrah, you wou'd not have come down my Chimney for nothing; you are a Rogue, I ſee by your Diſguiſe, Sirrah. Bind him, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Diſguiſe! hold, hold, if the Truth muſt out, it muſt; then to deal ingenuouſly—

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ah! now it comes out, I'm ruin'd paſt Redemption. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am very ſubject to an itching in my Nature to know every body's Concerns, and being thruſt out of an Officer's Lodgings of my Acquaintance, for my Impertinence (as he call'd it) I ſuſpected he had ſome Intrigue on foot: So I watch'd his coming out; but finding he ſhut himſelf up, I imagin'd he had got his Miſtreſs with him. So, Sir, I found means to get in again; but not meeting with him, I fancy'd he had ſome private way up the Chimney. So, Sir, my confounded Curioſity, with a Pox to't, muſt needs try to ſmell him out—So, Sir, I turn'd my Coat here to ſave it clean, and up I ſcrambl'd; but when I came without-ſide, I ſaw no body there then: Sir, ſomething whiſper'd me in my Ear, that he might be gone down the next Chimney: So, Sir, that deviliſh Deſire of mine brought me down hither, as you ſee, Sir; and this is the Truth, and nothing but the Truth, as I hope for your Pardon, Sir—Ah, poor Mar-plot, if this brings thee not off, thou art undone for ever. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p:
A well compact Lye. I'll Officer you, with the Devil to you. I ſuppoſe your Country-men think they have a Licenſe for Cuckoldom. Do you hear? ſearch the whole Houſe; for this Rogue in Red may lurk in ſome Corner or other, and
watch his Opportunity to preſs my Wife to the Service, and think to raiſe Recruits out of my Family: And for you, ſweet Senior Sweep-Chimney, the Corrigadore ſhall let you into the Secrets of our Laws in Portugal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Devil take all Secrets for me.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Lorenzo, go let him know his Preſence is requir'd. Come, Sir, I ſhall put you into a ſafer Place till he comes, where there is no Chimney to get out at. Margaritta, take care of my Wife—Hold, now I think on't, I'll eaſe you of that Trouble, and do it my ſelf. Go, get in there.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What Fault have I committed, my Dear, to be imur'd? If I had not cry'd out, you had not taken this Villain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wiſh you had been dumb, with all my Blood.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: When he is gone, and the Houſe found to be clear, you ſhall have your Liberty again; therefore no Diſpute, but in, I ſay.
Now bring him along into the next Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O you malignant Stars—Oh, take pity upon me, and let me go, or I ſhall die with Vexation, and you'll be acceſſary to my Murder, and that will trouble your Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Conſcience! you Heretick Dog; do you talk of Conſcience? Drag him along.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heretick Dog! a good Hint; ad, I'll pretend to turn Papiſt. Oh, hear me one Moment, Sir; I do confeſs I am a Heretick, and my Conſcience tells me very unfit to die. Ah, dear Sir, be ſo charitable to afford me a little Inſtruction, and recommend me to ſome Saint that may take care of me in the other World.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Oh, Anthony! thou haſt touch'd his Heart, and put me upon a meritorious Action—I muſt have regard to his poor Soul—Well, young Man, ſince I find thou art become the Care of Heav'n, I think thee worthy my Regard. I'll ſend for a Prieſt that ſhall inſtruct thee in the Myſteries of our Religion. Come, come along.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, for ſome Inſtructions how to get out; here's a little time gain'd however.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Well, by St. Anthony, I am much concern'd for him, methinks I feel a more than ordinary motion about my Heart. Ha! My pulſes beat quicker than they uſed to do; oh dear, how my Breaſts heave; I am much diſorder'd, but I believe my Diſtemper
wou'd not prove dangerous, were he my Phyſician; well, if I thought he would be grateful I'd releaſe him. I have a Key will open that Door; beſides, he knows my Lady's Gallant, and perhaps they may force him to diſcover who he is, and where he lodges; and if he falls into Don Lopez's Hands, fare him well, and farewel my Fees too; now if I convey him out, I may prevent future Miſchief, and may be get a Love of my own, at leaſt I cannot fail of Rewards from all ſides, I'll do't I'm reſolv'd.
Well Senior Engliſe, what think you of finding out ſecrets again?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For my part I ſhall hate every thing that is but ſpell'd with any one Letter that belongs to it: Have you no Bowels of Mercy for one neither? Ah, Seniora, for honeſt Charles's ſake let me go, you ſee I brought you off, then prethee take ſome pity on me

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Fie Senior, a Lady may compaſſionate your Perſon for your own ſake, to do you Juſtice, you are a clever young Man, and may make your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wiſh I cou'd make my Eſcape,

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Suppoſe a Lady ſhou'd take a liking to you, cou'd you be kind?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Kind? ods Heart, is it poſſible for a Man to think of kindneſs when the Knife's at his Throat—What the Devil does this old Hag mean?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: But ſet the caſe a Woman ſhou'd procure the liberty of your Perſon, what Charms muſt ſhe be Miſtreſs off to captivate your Heart?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Charms! Egad if ſhe had never a Noſe, I ſhould think my ſelf bound in Honour to be grateful.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Tho' ſhe was not altogether ſo young.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, tho' ſhe were as old again as thou art, I wou'd love her monſtrouſly. I fancy 'tis her ſelf ſhe means; egad I begin to conceive hopes of Liberty. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Indeed! And do you really think you cou'd love me, Senior?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do you really think you can let me out?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It lies in my Power.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why then t'other ſhall lye in my Will: And to prove my Love, there's Gold for thee, old Girl.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.p:
This is as it ſhould be now, nothing like Earneſt to bind
• Bargain—Well Senior, upon condition you'll meet me whenever I ſhall give you Notice, I'll take pity on you, and let you Eſcape.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Angel, my Life, my Soul; od I'm wondrous full of Raptures of a ſudden.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hark, I hear ſome Body coming, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With all my Spirit.

div.stage: Enter Don Perriera, and Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Stupidity! Give a Villain fair play for his Life, that wou'd rob you of your Honour! What buſineſs cou'd this Fellow have in your Houſe? And by ſo Clandeſtine a way as the Chimney? Where is he? give him to my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Nor for the World; you wou'd not kill him now, when he is willing to be Converted: Juſt when his Eyes are opening? That wou'd be to deſtroy his Soul with his Body.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: His Soul? I'd rather give a hundred Moydres to have it pray'd out of Purgatory, then loſe my Revenge. Open the Door I ſay, or I will force it open.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I ſay you ſhall not ſee him till the Corrigadore comes, I'll deliver him into the Hands of Juſtice; I will not have a Man murder'd without a juſt Cauſe; touch the Door if you dare, I'd have you to know I am Maſter of my own Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: And I'd have you to know, Sir, that I'll batter your Lodgings about your Ears, before I'll ſuffer in my Honour: Where is this ſalacious Woman, this adulterous Siſter, this Contaminated fair One, this Viper of our Family?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Safe enough out of your reach I know ſhe's innocent of this, and therefore will preſerve her. Pray mittigate your Paſſion, Senior, and you ſhall have all the ſatisfaction in this matter you can deſire from a Brother.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Brother! Dam the Alliance, I ſcorn the Title.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Right, juſt as my Wife ſaid—he does hate me heartily— [Enter Servant.] How now, is the Corrigadore come?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he's without.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Bring him in.

I charge you, Senior Don Garcia Pedro Compoſtello, to keep the Peace, and protect the Priſoner which I ſhall deliver into your Hands from the fury of Senior Don Lopez, whoſe fiery
Temper hurries him on to execute, before he knows the Nature of the Offence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake, Senior; Raſhneſs has no Connexion with true Courage; and I look upon Don Lopez to be a Perſon of a ſingular good Conduct.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Rot your fawning Praiſe—Do Juſtice, demand your Priſoner, let me ſee the Engliſh Dog.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay Senior, if you are in earneſt, I am oblig'd by my Offices to keep the Peace; diſarm him.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: A Curſe of your Authority.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Now Don Perriera, bring out the Offender.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: That I will. Here open that Door, and bring him hither.
sp.stage: [Gives a Key to a Servant; who Exits, and returns.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here is no Body within, Sir,

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: How! no Body within? Ah, thou art a blind Booby.
sp.stage: [Goes in, and returns haſtily, croſſing himſelf.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! The Rogue was in the right, there is no Body there, 'twas certainly the Devil, and he's gone through the Keyhole; for no Humane Creature cou'd get out; bleſs me, how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: The Devil! I wiſh I had met with that Devil, I'd have try'd to have made him Mortal for the good of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray let's ſee this Room from whence he eſcap'd, perhaps he may be hid ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Oh, it is to no purpoſe, there is nothing to be ſeen.

head.hi: [The Scene draws, and diſcovers them ſearching about.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Hark ye Don Perriera, if your Wife be not vaniſh'd too, prethee ask her what Species he was compos'd of, I warrant, ſhe can tell you, he had no ſulphureous Scent about him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis very odd; was the Door lock'd are you ſure?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Senior, I'm ſure I unlock'd it.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I lock'd it my ſelf, and have had the Key in my Pocket ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: But all your Locks are not ſecur'd, by carrying the Key about you. I doubt Senior, I hope I may put on my Spado again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray be certain of your Criminals, Senior, the next time you ſend for me.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: S'death! am I flouted—I have loſt all Patience, I'd give my whole Eſtate to know which way this Dog eſcap'd, if he were Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Ask your Wife that,—Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: My Wife! If I ſhou'd find my Wife guilty, I'd practice ſuch unheard of Cruelties on her, as ſhou'd out-do our Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Pſhaw! All Talk, all Talk; you ſhou'd have cruſh'd when in your Power, but then the Law muſt right you; you had a meritorious Work to do, there was ſo much care taken on his Soul, that you left the Body unguarded, and it has made bold to ſlip thro' your Fingers: Confound your Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Amen I ſay, with all my Heart, and ſend me more Senſe—I own my good Nature has abus'd me, but here I throw it off; and now, Senior, I am apt for any Impreſſion, your Will ſhall be my Law; ſay what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Why, if you will take my Advice, cauſe diligent ſearch to be made thro' all the Family, there is certainly a falſe Key to that Door, and thoſe you find it upon diſpatch, but rack 'em firſt to bring the Secret out.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: It ſhall be done. What more?

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: If you find it not, put on the ſame Humour you us'd to wear, ſeem not to ſuſpect my Siſter, but pretend ſome Buſineſs at St. Ubes for two or three Days; take your leave, return privately, and conceal your ſelf in ſome convenient Place: I warrant you'll make ſufficient Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: All this I'll obſerve to a tittle, and if I do find her falſe, by St. Anthony ſhe dies.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: In the mean time I'll not be Idle, my Revenge ſhall purſue theſe Engliſh Dogs ſo cloſe, that I'll find out this Villain, or write Villain on the Heart of all his Country-Men.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: A Curſe of the Cauſe that brought theſe Whore-maſters to Portugal. What a numerous Progeny will they leave behind them; the next Generation will be all Mungrils—But I'll endeavour to prevent the Increaſe in my Family.

l.hi: Woman, thy Conſtancy I go to try:
Bleſt if thou'rt true—but if you're falſe you die.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: HA, ha, ha; certainly this Fellow is the moſt miſchievous Rogue that ever liv'd; which way got he down the Chimney?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay that's paſt my finding out, as alſo what's become of him: I cou'd have cut his Throat with all my Soul juſt then, and yet I can't help being concern'd for him now, I fear he is kill'd.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be ſorry for that, tho' in my Conſcience he deſerves it, this buſie humour of his is as natural to him as his Food; he follow'd me home this Morning, I was forc'd to uſe him very roughly to get rid of him, for you muſt know, I have a trap Door in my Chimney, thro' which I deſcend into a back Street, where I am conducted by an old Negro to an Angel of a Woman; I had her Summons, and the hour of Aſſignation was come when he enter'd my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A very unſeaſonable Viſit, faith Colonel.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ay, was it not? but I quickly diſpatch'd him, tho' how he ſtumbl'd upon you afterwards, and in ſo odd a manner, is a miracle.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: If he lives we ſhall know when next we meet; I never catch'd him in a lye, which is the beſt Qualification he has: But Colonel, did not you promiſe to introduce me to your French Miſtreſs? What, this Lady incog. has not beat her out by the by, has ſhe Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: No, no, ſhe maintains her Ground too well, there's more danger of my raiſing the Siege, than her beating the Chamade; ſhe has ſo many retreats of Pride, Vanity, and Affectation, that without ſome lucky Accident toſs a Granade into the Magazine of her Inclination, there'll be no hopes of the Town.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Storm then, Colonel, ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I rather chuſe to block her up and ſtarve her out, ſuffer no Admirer to enter; and if once a Woman of her temper want the Proviſion of Vanity, ſhe ſurrenders of courſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: An admirable Stratagem, but prithee let me ſee her before you put it in practice.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: It ſhall be now, if you pleaſe, Charles.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With all my Heart: Is it far?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: At that Houſe, yonder.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Lead the way then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lead the way—where the Devil are they going? now can't I help having a violent deſire to follow them, tho' I ſcap'd ſo narrowly in my laſt Project: Yonder they go, ha! they are enter'd already, that is no publick Houſe I'm ſure: Egad, may be it is ſome private Bourdell, or what buſineſs can both of 'em have at one Houſe? Well, Charles, tho' you was ſo barbarous to deſert me in my Afflictions, I won't ſerve you ſo, I'll not ſtir from this place 'till I ſee you ſafe out—Od, upon ſecond thoughts I'll knock at the Door, and ask for him, perhaps three may be as welcome as two.
sp.stage: [As he is going to knock, enter Iſabinda in Boys Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha! Mar-plot here, this is lucky. [Aſide.] Mr. Marplot, fortunately met.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's more than I can tell yet, for I don't know you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nor wou'd I have you, [Aſide.] But you know thoſe that do; can you tell me where Mr. Charles Gripe is to be found?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha! my Mind miſgives me plaguily that this is an Envoy from the old Man's Wife, pray Heav'n he has never a Summons from my old Matron too; for tho' I comply'd with all ſhe ask'd to purchaſe my Liberty, I am ſure I ſhall have no Stomach to perform Articles. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Don't you hear me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, I hear you—What the duce ſhall I ſay to him, he muſt not know that Charles is gone into yon Houſe; for Women here, they ſay, are curſed Jealous, and that may be a means to have his Throat cut. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why don't you anſwer? where does he Lodge?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where does he Lodge?—this muſt be ſome new Intreague, for doubtleſs t'other knows his Lodgings: Look ye, Sir, one good turn deſerves another; let me know what buſineſs you have with him, and accordingly as I like it, your Queſtion ſhall be anſwered.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Mar-plot ſtill, I find he's no changling. [Aſide] Why then, Sir, if you muſt know, I have a Letter for him from a Lady who is deſperately in love with him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So, here's another Intreague popt into my Mouth. In Love with him? prithee dear Youth who is ſhe? where does ſhe live? What's her Name? Is ſhe Maid, Wife, or Widow? Young, or Old? Black, Brown, or Fair? Short, or Tall? Fat, or Lean? this Country, or a Foreigner? quick, quick, quick my dear little Rogue, let me into the ſecret, and I'll carry thee to his Lodgings immediately—Egad this Diſcovery will make my peace with Charles compleatly.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I can only anſwer him theſe queſtions, Sir, I am no Blab, you muſt excuſe me if I'm ſilent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So muſt you me, Sir, I'm no Blab neither, Sir, if you go to that, I'd have you to believe I can keep my Friend's ſecrets when intruſted; I don't know his Lodgings, find them out as you can.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are very ſhort, Sir; I have nothing to ſay againſt your ſecrecy, but it wou'd be Impudence in me to run the hazard, beſides foreſtalling your Friend's Generoſity, he ought to have the diſpoſal of his own ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, if it comes into his Hands once 'twill coſt me more pains to find out? than 'tis worth.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Pains to find out? I hope you never endeavour to find out what other People wou'd conceal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No? yes to chuſe; why the duce ſhou'd any Man know more than my ſelf? We came into the World alike, and I can ſee no occaſion for his ſuperior knowledge.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I admire you are not for levelling Eſtates too; how can you bear any Man to be richer than your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh with eaſe, my Wealth lies in my Mind, I had rather fathom the depth of a Man's Thoughts, than his Pockets; yet to ſhow you I can ſuppreſs my Curioſity, let me read the Letter, and I'll excuſe the reſt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: It is as much as my Life's worth to open the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pox take his Life—tell me what's in't then, or may I be carbonaded if you know his Lodgings. I'd give a Finger to have this Intreague rightly. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
I muſt not let this Fellow know me, if I intend to conceal my being in Lisbon; I'll humour him a little, and try what
diſcovery I can make. [Aſide.] Well, Sir, if you'll promiſe to be ſecret, I'll let you into this Affair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Secret as a Prieſt, Child—Egad I ſhall have it, pray Heav'n Charles does not come out before he has done, if he ſhou'd I ſhould be undone. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why then the Lady I belong to, is a rich Merchant's Daughter, near the Convent of Santo Vincente, her Name is Dona Cephiſa, ſhe ſaw your Friend at Church, is extremely charm'd with him, and reſolves to marry him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marry him! ha, ha, ha, ha, poor Lady! why now to return ſecret for your ſecret, he's Married already, but perhaps he may prick her down amongſt the reſt of his Miſtreſſes: You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Too well—the reſt of his Miſtreſſes? has he ſuch ſtore then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As many as he can well manage, I believe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh my Heart, the danger of intreaguing in this place alarms my fears, and ſhocks my very Soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What I have ſaid makes you thoughtful, I perceive; will no Body do but Charles? What think you of me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, were I a Woman, I ſhou'd prefer you before him, but I can't anſwer for my Lady; if you pleaſe I'll mention you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant, Sir,—Egad there may be new pleaſure in having an Intreague of ones own, for ought I know, for I never had one in my Life. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: But, Sir, there is one Article in our Agreement which you have not perform'd,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Where your Friend lodges?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why he lodges at yon green Windows, where if you have any Service from your Lady for your humble Servant, you'll find me there alſo.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir I kiſs your Hand, I'll do my beſt to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, I kiſs yours—I'm glad he's gone before Charles came out; this is a Nonſenſical Secret, tho' methinks I had rather know what the Colonel and he is doing in yon Houſe—Shall I knock at the Door or not? If I ſhou'd, ten to one but I do Miſchief—and ſhall be beaten again: To prevent which I'll wait
within ſight for their coming out, ſo when they are paſs'd by, I may with more Security make my Enquiry.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to Mademoiſel Joneton's Lodgings.

div.stage: She dreſt Fantaſtically modiſh, with her Siſter Marton, and two other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Suſan, bring me the Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Don't I look wretchedly to Day, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Your looks are the ſame to Day they always are, I ſee no Difference.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How do you mean that, Siſter? That I always look curſedly, or how?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: She looks too well for my Eaſe, ſince ſhe's belov'd by Colonel Ravelin. [Aſide.] I'm ſure your Vanity and Affectation does not put that Conſtruction upon my Words, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Affectation! Ladies, pray what am I affected in? Nay, take the Glaſs away again.
My Siſter Marton ſays, I'm affected, ſo I will not look in't, to oblige her: Am I not very compliſant, Ladies?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Mademoiſel Joneton is always ſo, I think you have the moſt agreeable manner of ſpeaking—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Fye Madam, how can you do your Reaſon ſo much Violence, to commend the moſt ridiculous Humour that ever Woman took up, it muſt needs be agreeable to hear Words ſpun out to half an Hours length.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Well, I muſt own I like it in her extremely, I think there is a particular Grace in't.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Yes, it is ſomething particular truly, ſometimes to talk as faſt as School-Boys read, and other ſome ſo ſlow, that we forget the Senſe of the Argument before ſhe has done ſpeaking.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: One wou'd really think my Siſter of Spaniſh Production, ſhe is ſo formal—I ſee no reaſon why one may not alter and change the Form and Manner of ſpeaking, according to the Company one keeps, as well as the Mode and Faſhion of one Clothes—Now when I converſe with my own Sex, I love to indulge my ſelf, and let my Words fall from me with Indolence and Eaſe, becauſe their Converſation is inſipid, and we only prattle away time.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Inſipid! Ha, ha, ha, pray what reliſh have the Mens beyond ours?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh, that Queſtion is Prepoſterous—But you have no Taſte Siſter, you deteſt Mankind.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Ay, but the Colonel has found the way to Convert that Notion. [Aſide.] I confeſs, Siſter, I never cou'd ſee any thing in thoſe lordly Creatures of force enough to make me ſubmit blindly to their tyrannick Sway.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But there's a vaſt Pleaſure in making them ſubmit to ours, to make ſo fine a Gentleman as Colonel Ravelin obey my Nod, ſigh, weep and kneel at ones Frown, then give him Raptures with a Smile. The Colonel! Oh! the moſt engaging Man alive—When he comes next you ſhall ſee him, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Not for the Spaniſh Mines—I am too well acquainted with the Colonel, which ſhe muſt not know. [Aſide.] Excuſe me Siſter, I ſhou'd only ſpoil your Converſation.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Does Madamoiſel Marton hold her Reſolution of a Moneſtery yet?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: have not yet laid aſide all Thoughts on't, Madam—tho' 'tis in the Colonel's Power to make me do it, I fear. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well, follow your own way, get up to a Six a Clock Maſs, then ſtitch till Dinner, tattle away your Hours with two or three ſilly Women, till Veſpers; then work again till Bedtime; and have no Pleaſure beyond a Dream.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Oh wou'd I cou'd retrieve that tranquil State, ſhe talks of what I was. [Aſide.] Every one to their Inclinations, Siſter.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: But pray inform me, Madamoiſel Joneton, for I am very Ambitious of coping you, where lies the Magick in Men to alter your manner of ſpeaking?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Deſire to pleaſe ſets all the Senſes in a Ferment, and Inclination preſſes ſo hard upon the Faculty of Speech, that our Words hurry out with Precipation, Vanity muſters the Force of our Charms, and Pride leads us on the attack of our Wiſhes, and a janty Variety of Airs compleat the Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's Collonel Ravelin and another Gentleman to wait on you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bring 'em up; une outer Galant.
sp.stage: [Riſing in a hurry, and running to the Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Ha! the Collonel, oh my Heart: I muſt be gone, I wou'd not have him know me for the World—Well, Siſter, I'll leave you to your deſirable Company.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Adieu, ma Soer—ah Maria Mater! how I look to day, je ſuis lead comme le diable.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: We'll wait on you another time, Mademoiſel.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: When you pleaſe, my dear Ladies.
Ah Monſieur le Colonel, je ſuis ravi de vous voir.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ah Madmoiſel Joneton, je meur tout le moment que je ete abſant de vous.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Ah Cela galant, ha, ha, ha, I have a moſt comical Story to tell you, ha, ha, ha; ſuch an Amour, ha, ha, ſuch a Letter, ha, ha, ſuch a Conqueſt; le pleaſer une Chatulez, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Oh pleaſant Raviſhment, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is it that is ſo Raviſhing, Colonel, in your Opinion? [Very gravely.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well Queſtion'd.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Your Letter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Then have you ſeen it, ma chear Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Not I, Madam, I depend upon your ſuperior Judgment for the Merit.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Moſt politely ſaid: You are certainly the beſt bred Man in Europe, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I am ſure this is the worſt proof of his being ſo I ever knew him give. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You are certainly the moſt polite diverting charming Woman that ever told a Story; but pray proceed, Madam; the Letter, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh ridiculous! a Letter from a High Dutch Servant; you ſhall hear it Colonel.
Ha, ha, ha, methinks it has a rumbling ſound.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: He makes Love like a Cannon, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A mon Dieu! What makes me ſo merry? I am ſure I have cauſe enough to the contrary; my poor Paroquet is dead, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Dead, it died upon my Hand, it talk'd and buſs'd me to the laſt moment; oh my Heart is broke, oh, oh, oh, oh,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: So ſhe's reſolv'd to play over all her tricks I ſee. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh I can't contain my ſelf when I think on't, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Oh unlucky Accident; give her Air.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: In my Opinion ſhe has already too much of that.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Mrs. Suſan, looſe her Lace; within there, bring ſome cold Water.
She revives; for Heav'ns ſake how do you do, Madam? Come, I'll procure you another Paroquet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh not ſo divertiſant, it had a thouſand pretty Actions; one day as Monſieur le Markee de belle Jambe was entertaining me with a Recital of his Amours—ha, ha, ha, I have a pleaſant Tale to tell you of him too, ha, ha, ha, he's marriy'd, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Upon the titter again, deliver me from ſuch a medley I ſay. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: To a thirty thouſand Pound Fortune, ha, ha, but the Eſtate lies in terra incognita, I have recommended Imagination for his Steward, and Philoſophy for his Equipage, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: The Marquiſs let into the ſecret, ha, ha, pray who is the Lady that has done him the favour?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh my Stars what ails me? ah Maria Mater, the Room goes round.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: A Chair there, Mrs. Suſan; repoſe your ſelf a little, Madam, 'tis only Vapours and will off again; theſe affectations in another I ſhou'd hate, but here I'm fated to the folly.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Moſt fantaſtical: the duce take me if I can bring my ſelf to the Complacence of asking her how ſhe does. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: How do you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh much better, Colonel, 'tis impoſſible any Malady can ſtay long in your Company; I admire your Friend can be ſo melancholy with a Companion ſo diverting.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I confeſs the Colonel is of a ſingular good humour, Madam, for an Engliſhman; we, generally ſpeaking, are dull heavy thinking Animals, not mov'd by the loſing of a Father.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Moſt unpolite, ſuch a Lover as this would make me as ſplenetick as fourſcore.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, he's married.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p:
Married! nay then I forgive him;—yet upon ſecond thoughts, I won't neither, for he ought to have left his dogged
Humours at home, and not ſtamp Wife in the Forehead of every Woman he meets.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: He's mad that wou'd ſtamp any thing upon thee, I'm ſure. [Aſide.] Since I offend you, Madam, I humbly take my leave. [Going.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I beg you wou'd excuſe the bluntneſs of my Friend, Madam, he's a very honeſt Fellow. Oh that I cou'd look upon her with his indifference. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh fie Colonel, why that requeſt? Your Friend is a fine Gentleman—Mais je ne ſcay pas en qui—Nay, you ſhan't go, Monſieur; you being a married Man, muſt underſtand every thing that belongs to our Sex.
sp.stage: [Runs and pulls him back by the Coat.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Heav'n deliver me from the Study. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; poor Charles, how he frets. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here! give me your Opinion, how do you like theſe Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: As I like every thing elſe that belongs to them, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A very odd Expreſſion that—but don't you think our Airs plus Engageant, than the Ladies in England, Monſieur? How did your Lady dreſs, to catch your Heart?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I never minded the Airs of her Perſon, Madam, ſhe had other Charms for me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This Fellow will give me the Hip confoundedly, if he goes on thus—What! ſhe ſings; I fancy you love ſinging, Monſieur—come I'll oblige you.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: She reſolves to teaze him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well, Monſieur, Comment agrez vous cela?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Words are very pretty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: And your manner of ſinging extremely engaging.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: That's not your Friend's Opinion, Colonel: He has certainly no Soul. If all his Sex were ſuch mortifying Animals, what a number of faſting Days ſhou'd we have in the Kalender; we ſhou'd have no need of Indulgences, Pardons, and Penance; we ſhou'd live Saints, and dye without the fear of Purgatory. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Colonel, you'll excuſe me if I leave you, for faith ſhe has tired my Patience. [Aſide to Rav.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: No, prithee tarry a little longer.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What are you two whiſpering about? You ſhan't go 'till you have drank ſome Tea; Suſan, get Water for Tea, and ſet the Table ready.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: 'Tis ready in the next Room, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: My Friend is a lover of Tea, and was juſt enquiring of me where I thought the beſt was to be got.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Devil take his Excuſe, now there is no getting off. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: That I am Miſtreſs of any thing worth his Admiration, is no ſmall pleaſure to me; I dare be vain to ſay, I can recommend him to the beſt in Portugal. Along Meſſieurs. Fa, la, la, lera lal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They ſtay a curſed while, Egad I'll e'en ask for Charles; the Story this young Fellow brought of a Letter will be a rare excuſe. [Going up to the Door.

div.stage: Enter a Bravo with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bravo.
sp.p: What Countryman are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Countryman, Sir? why I am an Engliſhman, Sir, I'm not aſham'd of my Country.

sp.speaker: Bravo.
sp.p: I have a Letter for an Engliſhman, but thoſe that ſent it don't know his Name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: From a Lady I warrant? Egad here's another Intreague of ſome Bodies pop'd in my way now; I've a good mind to own the Letter, open it and ſee what's in't; but if it ſhou'd come from the old Woman—Pray, Sir, does it come from Youth or Age?

sp.speaker: Bravo.
sp.p: From Youth and Fire, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Becauſe I expect a Summons from a very beautiful young Lady my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bravo.
sp.p: Your Deſcription is juſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir, why then I believe it is for your humble Servant, Sir. Diſcoveries come thick to day.
I am a lucky Dog, Faith.

sp.speaker: Bravo.
sp.p: Not unlikely; there it is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Ah Colonel, ah Charles, what wou'd you give to be in
my place now? But hang it, I'm good-natur'd, ſhe ſhall fall to one of your ſhares, for I wou'd not give a Half-penny for the fineſt Woman in Lisbon, for my own ſake. [Opens and reads.] What's here? The Reader is a Villain, and deſerves to have his Throat cut. Surpriſing! upon my Soul, Sir, this Letter does not belong to me. I am a lucky Dog now indeed.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, Sir, you lie. Draw Sirrah, or I'll rip your Guts up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Draw, Sir? for what, Sir? Oh bloody-minded Wretch, what will come of me? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: For opening the Letter, Villain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah pox of my Curioſity—The Devil take the Letter, 'twas none of my ſeeking, the Fellow ſaid it was for an Engliſhman, an, an, an I did not know but it might have been for me as well as another; I ask your Pardon with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Rot your Compliment; if it had come from my Siſter it had been for you, Sir; therefore Draw, or by St. Anthony—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Siſter! as I hope to be ſav'd, Sir, I know never a Man's Siſter in the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Cowardly Dog, [beats him.] dare to lie with a Man's Wife, and not dare to fight for her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, I lie with a Man's Wife? oh, Sir, you are the moſt miſtaken in me that ever you was in your days, Sir; Upon my Faith, I never knew what Woman was, nay, Sir, I never car'd for a Woman, that's more—But indeed here is two or three Gentlemen of my Acquaintance very much given that way.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Is there ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh exceedingly—now I won't ſwear it is not one of them. I wiſh I were fairly rid of him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Your Safety depends upon your Information, let me know where to find them, and you ſhall live.

div.stage: Enter Colonel Ravelin and Charles behind them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thank you heartily, Sir,—What a curſed Premenary I have brought my ſelf into now, for Egad I'll not tell where Charles lives, if I dye for't—I'll, I'll, I'll tell him a wrong Place, I'm reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Come, where do they lodge? What are you ſtudying for, ha?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, I, I, I, can't think of the name of the Street for my Blood—it is, it is—what de ye call the Street when you turn the Corner of your right Hand, and then turn again of your left, and then again of the right, and ſo back by the left, an, an, an, ſo, an, an a croſs the what de call 'em, an, an.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: No equivocating, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I thought it was Mar-plot's Voice.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Since he lives, well preſerve him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, good Sir, I, I, I, I, I,—Ah Charles, dear Charles.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Guard your Life, Sir, or ceaſe to inſult this Gentleman.
sp.stage: [They beat off Don Lopez and the Bravo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Victoria! Victoria! Faith Gentlemen you came in the lucky Minute, or I had been a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Nay, in my Conſcience I believe thou'lt never die in thy Bed. Which of your inquiſitive Actions brought this upon you?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Was this your Chimney Adventure, or another?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, faith this was another, about a damn'd Letter, and Cuckolding ſome Body, and debauching that Spaniard's Siſter, and the Devil knows what; I wiſh one of you two is not at the bottom of this.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ha, ha! come Charles, we'll to your Lodgings, where he ſhall give us the whole Relation of his Adventures.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With all Sincerity—and I have ſomething elſe to tell you, Charles; there's a Lady in Love with you, and has ſent you a Letter, but mum, you ſhall promiſe to let me into the Secret, or you ſhall know no more on't.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How brisk the Rogue is again already? I thought you might have had enough of Secrets.
