sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, the Mind you know is never ſatisfy'd.
Were all the Joys that Nature could beſtow
Within my Power to taſte, I'd rather know
What every Man endeavours ſtill to hide;
And having that, wou'd care for nought beſide.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Charles, Colonel Ravelin and Mar-plot.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: A Very pretty Account, ha, ha, ha, what do you expect will be the end of your Curioſity, Mar-plot?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No good in this Country I fear, yet for my Blood I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What, can't you help dogging People, and opening Letters of no Concern to you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O' my Soul, I have made Reſolutions upon Reſolutions to the contrary, but to no purpoſe; there is a tickling deſire runs thro' my Veins, which is always craving as my Stomach—and makes theſe Diſcoveries as neceſſary as my Food. Tho' faith I never mean any harm—Why this Letter now, who the Devil dream'd of a conſumed Challenge?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You ſhou'd always dream of the worſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's not my Maxim, Colonel; methinks ill luck comes faſt enough. Look ye Gentlemen, 'tis as much your fault as mine, if you wou'd take me with you, or tell me the bottom of things, I ſhou'd trouble my Head no farther; but here you leave me in the Dark, and nothing to do, but entertain my Fears, which are ſtrong for my Friends, and moſt of the Miſchiefs I do, proceeds from my Concern for their Safety; and here I get thump'd and beaten for my good Intentions, and that's all, on every ſide.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And all you deſerve; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There's a Gentleman below inquires for you, Sir; he has Buſineſs with you from England, he ſays, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: From England! who the Devil can this be now? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Bring him up.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I have a Letter and Packet for Mr. Charles Gripe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I am the Perſon, Sir. Robin, reach a Chair; pray be pleas'd to ſit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: From England! Ha, ha, Sir, your humble Servant; why this is the very Gentleman I told you of, Charles—So, ſo, well, well, and how does Donna Cephiſa? What, ſhe will have him then, and no Body elſe? ha? What does ſhe ſay to you, Charles? Ha? How does ſhe write, Ha? Nay, egad you ſhall let me into this Buſineſs, Mun—for I have been chief Promoter of it I am ſure, therefore no ſhuffling, Charles—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No, no, I ſcorn it, Mar-plot; there read, read.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why that's civil now—Let me ſee how theſe Spaniſh Dames expreſs themſelves—My deareſt Life—Humph—As frank and fond, as if it came from an Inhabitant of Covent-Garden, egad—I hope this will find you ſafely arriv'd in Lisbon—Ha, Liſbon—Why what the Devil does ſhe mean? Lets ſee what's at bottom: From your ever loving Wife, Iſabinda Gripe. A murrain Gripe you—Piſh, Pox, I wonder'd you was ſo ready to ſhow it me indeed.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what does not the Secret pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pleaſe a Fiddle-ſtick; why what did this young Dog mean? Egad I wiſh Charles wou'd beat him for the Diſappointment. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: to Iſab.] Pardon my Memory, Sir, I have ſeen your Face ſomewhere, but cannot recollect where.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Heav'n continue his Ignorance. [Aſide.] Very likely, Sir, I have liv'd moſt of my time in this Place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay; why how in the Name of Wonder did he come by this Letter then? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Factor to my Uncle, Sir Francis Tradewell, from whom I receiv'd that Pacquet, with Orders to deliver it to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, ſo it came. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I know Sir Francis very well, and for his ſake, Sir, ſhou'd be prowd of being better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, you Honour me—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pies of his Acquaintance, I ſay. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I hope your Lady's well, Charles.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
At your Service, Colonel—She has ſent the Papers I told you I forgot; now I ſhall diſpatch my Buſineſs very quickly, ſhe ſongs to ſee me, ſhe ſays—'tis a Poor good-natur'd Tit, and I lov'd her heartily till I married her; but whether her Overfondneſs, or the eaſy Acceſs every Man has to his Wife, takes off the edge
of my Appetite, but methinks I ſee her not with half that deſire I us'd to do, when I ſcal'd her Window for a Kiſs, the Memory of it ſtill is Pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay! my Shoulders remember that time too.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ungenerous Declaration, 'tis very unjuſt in my Opinion to ſlight the thing that loves you, I'm ſure 'tis what I cou'd not do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I fancy you never try'd the Matrimonial ſtrength of Inclination yet, Sir, therefore can be no Judge: Nature abhors Conſtraint.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ay ay, Inconſtancy is a fault in Nature, and who can help it?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Right, Colonel! and when you marry Mademoiſel Flutter yonder, you'll have a Proof of what I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mademoiſel Flutter, who's ſhe? I never heard of her before. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Let her look to that—I thought Charles's Wife had been a Favorite of yours, Mr. Mar-plot, but I don't hear you make the leaſt Inquiry after her Health.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Look ye, Colonel, I hate to be baulk'd, for that puts every thing out of ones Head—Hark ye, what did you mean by telling me ſuch a confounded Story upon the Terriera de Paſſe, of a rich Merchant's Daughter Dona Cephiſa, and I can't tell who? What, was it all but a ſham then?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, you was ſo inquiſitive, that I had no other way to diſmiſs you, and it is not my Cuſtom to let one Man into the Affairs of another.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Poor Mar-plot, thou art baulk'd every way; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, there was never good times ſince this ſhuffling and lying came in Faſhion.
sp.stage: [A Letter ty'd to a Stone, is toſs'd in at the Window, Charles takes it up and Reads to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha day! Where the Devil came that from?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: ſeeming to look out.] I fancy it came from that Fellow which looks up yonder, there is no Body elſe near—Ha, my Eyes deceive me, or he belongs to ſome Body in the Houſe where I lodge—I'll home, and make the beſt Obſervation I can in this matter. Ah, poor Charles, theſe Courſes are more dangerous than thou art aware of; I'll not diſcover my ſelf yet, perhaps I may ſatisfie my Curioſity better as I am. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: An Aſſignation, Charles; ſend thee better Fortune than laſt time.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: 'Tis from the ſame Woman, Colonel—No, no, 'tis only ſome roguiſh Boy, toſſing Stones about in Pieces of his Copy-Book.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Humph, but that ſham won't take tho'. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh well diſſembel'd—Sir, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir, I hope I ſhall have the Honour to ſee you here again.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, the Honour will be mine.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: The Trap-door is unbolted, Colonel. [Half aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that of a Trap-door now? Ods heart here's two confounded Intreagues on Foot, and I'm out at both, and they'll be hang'd before they'll let me into one of them. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I'll be there immediately.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where, Colonel? I wiſh I cou'd ſpilt my ſelf in half now, that I might follow them both.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Again at your Impertinence? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: He can't help it for his Soul—Tho' we take different Poſts, Colonel, I fancy 'tis one and the ſame Action, Proſperity to yours.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: The ſame to thine. Mr. Mar-plot, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ſhall I do between both? Pox on't, 'tis very unlucky—Then you won't let me into the Secret, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Poſitively no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, Charles, you won't both leave me, will you?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Indeed, Mar-plot, I have extraordinary Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do but tell me what it is, nay, tell me but ſomething relating to't, and I am ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why then to be ingenious, the Letter which was toſs'd in is a Challenge, and I am going to ſeek for a Second; now if you cou'd Fight, you'd ſave me the Labour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, the Devil take it, that I never learn'd to Fence—Why did you not engage the Colonel?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Becauſe I ſaw he had Affairs of his own to purſue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What wou'd I give for Courage now—Pies on't, what is it that makes Men ſo ſtout? Egad I'm ready to weep to think I can't ſerve my Friend, I have the Theory of fighting, methinks—I only want the practick Part.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: So, I have found the way to drop him at laſt—Well, I hope you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Satisfied? no faith, Charles, I am not ſatisfied; ods Life, I'll tell you what I can do, I'll Charge my brace of Pocket Piſtols, and ſhoot him—if you will.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh fye, there's a diſhonourable Action indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Devil take Honour; when Life's concern'd, what will a Man get by't?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I have not time at preſent to clear that Queſtion, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Farewel! Egad 'twou'd be faring very ill tho' if he ſhou'd be kill'd. I wiſh I knew where to find Colonel Ravelin—Oh Lord, oh Lord; I never thought to ask Charles where this Duel was to be fought, and then whither cou'd I ſend him? Well thought on, yonder he goes, I'll follow till I fix him, and then I'll ſoon call Company enough to part them—Egad I love my Friend, as I love my Life.

div.stage: Enter Charles with a Rope-ladder, Mar-plot at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Let me ſee, ſhe has chang'd her Appartment, ſhe has ſent me Word—Her Window now is over the Door, this muſt be it.
sp.stage: [Throws up his Ladder, which falls down again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Humph, I ſee what kind of Challenge it is now; a Man muſt have a rare fighting Stomach, that will ſcale the Window of his Antagoniſt.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Here, here, Senior, the Coaſt is clear, come in at the Door boldly, my Lady is all Impatience to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Mine is the greateſt; in, in my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: [Sings.] Ah, put her in mind how her time ſteals on—Oh, Charles, the Devil a Second did you want; that was only a ſham to get rid of me. Ha, ha, ha, how comically things jump in my way? I'll ſecure the Ladder tho' for him; this is a great Houſe, but whoſe it is, is the Query? If I thought I ſhou'd not have my Bones broke, I wou'd make bold to Enquire—Who
sp.stage: Enter behind him Don Perriera, and Don Lopez.
sp.p:
have we here? They ſeem in deep Conſultation—Oh bleſs me,
one of them is the Bloody-minded Spaniard, egad it is not ſafe to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I have done all you order'd me to a tittle, and have taken leave of my Wife for three Days, under pretence of Buſineſs at St. Ubes.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: That's well I can't find who this Villain is, but I warrant we ſhall have him faſt enough. Now do you return, and cunningly convey your ſelf into the Antichamber-cloſet, there lye conceal'd, he'll not be long abſent, if he's not there already; in the mean time I'll wait in the Street, with two or three truſty Fellows, that ſhall diſpatch him if he falls in our way.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: And if I find my ſelf a Cuckold, fire, blood and brimſtone, if I catch 'em, I'll ſend them both to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, what an Oath was that? Why certainly, they think Murder a venial Sin here, and make no more of killing a Man, then cracking a Nut. This is certainly Charles which they threaten, for the old Cacademon is gone into that Houſe; which way ſhall I give Charles notice of his danger? I have a good mind to cry our Fire; ay, but when they find there is no ſuch thing, they may burn me perhaps—Hark, I hear ſome Body coming, 'gad I ſhall be beat again.

My Fear hears double, I think, I can ſee no Body—Od I'll make uſe of this Ladder; he talk'd her Appartment was over the Door, ſo that perhaps I may give him warning at the Window, and he may come down the ſame way—Oh lord, which is the Houſe, now? Is it this, or this, I wonder; choke me if I can tell what a blundering Sot was I not to take better notice, this muſt be it certainly, [Seems to throw up the Ladder between the Scenes, and Exit.] Heav'n ſend me good luck, for I tremble horridly.

head.hi: SCENE draws and diſcovers Marron's Apartment.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Nay this is ſtarving a Man in the ſight of Plenty; how many times have you put me off with Excuſes and fair Promiſes▪

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: And how often have you ſworn Conſtancy, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Why you won't give me leave to be conſtant, my Dear; let me once poſſeſs, and then.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: And then Mademoiſel Joneton's Charms will be ſufficient to excuſe the Perjury.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ha! how does ſhe know my Pretenſions there? I fancy I ſhall have warmer buſineſs by and by than I expected. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be not ſurpriz'd at my knowledge of that Affair, nor apprehenſive of the leaſt danger, tho' I know you love her, ſpight of all her Affectation, ſhe's the darling Miſtreſs of your Soul, yet you are ſafe, I ſcorn thoſe poor Revenges which my Sex too often take; 'tis the Heart, not the Life, I'd make my Prize.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Generouſly ſaid,—But you are miſinform'd, Madam. I'll carry it off if poſſible—She's handſome, and I don't find my Love to the other renders me incapable of a Compliment to this. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: She has too much Vanity, Colonel, to keep your Paſſion a Secret, and it is diſhonourable in you to deny your Love.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Humph! Look you, Madam, I am a true Proteſtant, and have a mortal Antipathy to Confeſſion; I bear the Queen's Commiſſion, and will entertain all that will fairly liſt under me; then let me have no more of theſe little Jealouſies; I'll make as good Proviſion for thee as for any Lady in Portugal, ſo prithee let's come to a right Underſtanding; if thou art plagu'd with an old ſuperannuated Husband, who wants a young Fellow to aid and aſſiſt him, here he ſtands; if thou'rt a Widow, and wants one to manage the Affairs of Love, I'll give you my word you can't have a better; I'm an Arithmetician, as well as a Soldier, and can caſt Account as faſt as any Man: And if thou'rt a Virgin, Egad I'm as good an Engineer. [Embracing her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You have miſtaken your Plan, and may raiſe the Siege, Colonel, for you'll ne'er carry the Town this way; I own I love you, and if I ſaid with more Sincerity than ſhe, I fancy I ſhou'd not injure her Paſſion; my Birth's as noble, my Fortune not leſs; you give me ſome Proofs indeed, that my Perſon falls ſhort of her Charms to engage the Heart of Colonel Ravelin.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Thy Perſon? thy Perſon is a charming Perſon, and my Heart, and all the reſt of the Appurtenances, are at thy Service, my Dear; thy Birth and Fortune are things indifferent, ſo no more to be ſaid about them. [Hugging her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Will you marry me then?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Ah! what a Turn's there? Who cou'd have thought, after thy manner of proceeding, thou wou'dſt have ask'd ſuch Security; why thou art an Uſurer in Love, but prithee uſe a Conſcience; don't expect a Man to be a Slave all his life. Marriage! why what confounded Extortion is that! ods heart thou art more mercenary than an Agent; look ye, Madam, I'll give you Heart for Heart, and I think that good lawful Int'reſt, and thou ſhalt have my Body for performance of Articles.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Ah, Colonel, you'll bring a Habeas Corpus, and remove it as ſoon as the Campaign begins. I don't like theſe Priſoners at large.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: And great Souls hate Reſtraint.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I have him faith—ah, how cloſe they are, Egad, it grieves me to part 'em—but there is no help for't—Fly, Charles, fly, there's the Devil and all of Plots againſt you—here, here, give me your hand, come this way thro' the Window.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Oh! a Man at my Window! oh! my Reputation is undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: How's that? a Man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Devil! the Colonel!—Zounds, I am certainly bewitch'd—I, I, I, had as good faln into the Hands of Turks and Tartars. O Lord, O Lord, my Ladder is gone, what ſhall I do now?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Mar-plot. S'death you Son of a Whore, I'll make an Example of you, to all inquiſitive Raſcals in the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, Colonel, for Heav'ns ſake ſave my Life; upon my Soul you'll make me break my Neck, for I hang only by my Hands; may I be ſlic'd into Collops, if I knew any thing of your being here; certainly I am the moſt unfortunate Fellow breathing.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Zounds come down Sirrah, and ceaſe your bawling, or I'll ſhoot you thro' the Head.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, I will, I will, I will, dear Colonel,

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: runs to Marton.] For Heav'n ſake, Madam, don't be frighted! 'tis an honeſt fooliſh Fellow of my Acquaintance, there's no danger of your Reputation, my Angel.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What Noiſe was that? ha! what do I ſee? My Siſter and the Colonel? ah, ah!

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Confuſion! ſhe here? I'm betray'd: What, ho, within there.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Ha! my Siſter! nay then I'm compleatly wretched. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, now we ſhall be murder'd—Oh Lord, what do you mean by calling out, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: S'death, what did you mean, Raſcal, by coming here? This Miſchief is all owing to you. I have a good mind to cut your Throat. [Runs to Marton.] Madam, Madam; ods heart was ever Man in this condition? What ſhall I do between 'em? Run Sirrah, and call ſome Body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord, Colonel, have a little Patience; ſee, ſee, ſhe revives.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Is this your Reſervedneſs, this your Modeſty, this your hating Mankind, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: How's that, her Siſter? I have made a fine piece of work, Faith: Raſcal, I cou'd find in my Heart to beat your Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Look ye, Colonel, be merciful, and if I don't bring all this buſineſs off clear, I'll forfeit my Neck, that's all.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Hang your Contrivance; nothing proſpers you have a Hand in.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You have decent Inclinations for a Nun; you had a mind for a taſte of the World before you left it, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: The World—the World is ſurfeited with your Impertinence, and I wou'd avoid taſting what may breed a feaver.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why, what an Inundation of Miſtreſſes has this Colonel? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: If he is ſo good a Phyſician, how comes yours to rage ſo high, Madam? Methinks you are delirious—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: It wou'd not be amiſs to confirm your Opinion—
sp.stage: [Goes to ſtrike her a Box on the Ear, but Col. Ravelin ſtops her Hand.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Madam; for Heav'ns ſake, Ladies, let's have no Petticoat War.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay! See what Example does, Colonel; Egad, Boxing's as catching as the Small-Pox—Nay, pray Madam let it go round—od if I were a Woman, I cou'd Box titely, but a pox on theſe Swords, they Spitchcock a Man in a Moment.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Did not your Temper carry a Puniſhment in its ſelf, I ſhould return the Favour you deſign'd me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Shou'd! And won't you Madam? Egad, I'd fain ſee them pull one anothers Coifes.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Dog, miſchievous Toad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh your moſt humble Servant, Colonel—I wiſh your Toes were not quite ſo Complaiſant. Their Intriegues tumble comically in my way—But egad, I pay a tragical price for my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Whatever Face this Accident may wear, Madam, give me leave to clear my ſelf—upon Honour—I have not—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Ceaſe your odious Excuſes, in vain you endeavour to be well with me—and the civilleſt Action you can do, is to quit the Room—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That we ſhall immediately Madam; upon my Soul, it was no deſign of ours to come into it, for to be plain with you Ladies, I am only in fault, and yet not in fault neither, for you muſt know that I luckily, or unluckily, as it may fall out—

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: What, in the name of Jupiter, is he a going to ſay?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Chanc'd to over-hear a Quarrel between a Friend of ours and a Portugueſe; the latter was foil'd in the Duel, and fled into your Neighbourhood here; but our Friend being a mettl'd Fellow, purſu'd him into the very Houſe. Seeing that, Madam, away ran I, and call'd this Gentleman to his Aſſiſtance; but finding every Door ſhut, and being very impatient to ſuccour our Friend, as I told you, Madam, we reſolv'd to ſcale the Window; but for want of taking good Notice, we miſtook the Houſe, it ſeems, and ſo happen'd in here. The Sight of two Men at the Window ſurpriz'd that Lady, and threw her into Fits—Compaſſion for the Sex made the Colonel fall foul upon me—And ſo this created the Buſtle, which brought you, Madam; an, an, an, ſo, ſo, ſo, an, an, that's all, Madam—Pray Heav'n this brings us off. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Excellent Fellow! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p:
The Dog deſerves to be forgiven for this plauſible Pretence; I'll ſtrike in with him—This is matter of Fact,
Ladies; yet ſure there is a Fate in all I do, which guides my Steps ſtill towards ſomething that relates to you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well there is a Beauty in that Expreſſion, 'twas a ſurprizing Accident,—Can you forgive my raſh Suſpicions, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: And our unlucky Adventure—What induces me to hope your Pardon, is your being related to this Lady, whoſe good Humour cancels all Faults as ſoon as acknowledg'd—for her ſake then.—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Ungrateful! For her ſake! Methinks I hate him now, nay, hate my ſelf for indulging a fooliſh Paſſion, equally deſtructive to my Eaſe and Fame—that has reduc'd me to this low Contempt, but with this Breath I baniſh the ſoft Paſſion from my Breaſt, and will this moment reaſſume my former Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You ſeem out of Humour, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Have I not Reaſon, but 'tis paſt; the Gentleman wou'd be forgiven for your ſake, but I forgive him for my own, reſolving to let nothing ruffle that Calmneſs with which my Soul's poſſeſt at preſent, for this Day ſhuts me from the World and you for ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean by that now? But Colonel, Charles will be kill'd—

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, enough, the Jeſt will grow ſtale. 'Tis pity ſo much Youth and Beauty ſhould be ſacrificed to a Cloyſter, for if I apprehend you right, 'tis that you mean, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wiſh they were both there, ſo that Charles was but out of Danger. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: 'Tis only there I can my Peace retrieve,
Where ſeeing nothing, nothing can deceive:
Shut from your ſight, my Wiſhes I'll controul,
Imure my Body, to preſerve my Soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Turn Nun! Who wou'd have thought it? So, there's an end of one Intreague.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Some forty years hence, perhaps, I may follow her Example—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Upon my Soul Colonel, Charles is in danger.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: What do you mean? 'Sdeath I'll toſs you out the ſame way you came in, you long to ſpoil all again—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Spoil the Devil—I tell you, he is in one of theſe Houſes, I ſaw him go in, and heard an old Cuckold ſwear what
he'd do if he caught him with his Wife; and then egad went into that very Houſe. My eagerneſs to give Charles notice of the Danger, tumbled me a top of you, a pies on't; and tho' I have brought you off, you are for toſſing me out at Window. Egad I think no Man meets ſuch barbarous returns for his good Nature, as I do.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Nay, if Charles is really in Danger, I beg your Pardon with all my Heart, Mr. Mar-plot.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is this Conſultation about? Et bein Monſieur, who are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Of you, Madam: Inclination and Honour holds Diſpute, Inclination chains me to your Preſence, but Honour calls me to the reſcue of my Friend: And I hope his Diſtreſs will excuſe my abrupt Departure. Adieu, ma chear ange.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And will you then precipitate your ſelf into danger? This Gentleman will go—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She's very charitably inclin'd towards me, I thank her. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Won't you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why look ye Madam, I, I, I will go with all my Heart, but, but, but, but,

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: But a ſingle Arm is weak Aſſiſtance, where the danger is ſo ſtrong—beſides it would be a Reflection upon mine Honour—You are my Guardian Angel, if you ſmile I ſhall return in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Faith is the main Point of Religion: Pray take me into your Protection too, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: So, he is gone then; now wou'd not I give a Diſh of Tea for a Lover that I could not make ſacrifice every thing to me. Theſe Engliſhmen have too much Senſe to make Huſbands on:

l.hi: For only he ſhou'd to our Sex be dear,
Who from a Look is capable of Fear.
The Man of Courage lords it every where.

head.hi: SCENE, The Inſide of Dona Perriera's Houſe.

div.stage: Dona Perriera and Charles at Supper, Margaritta waiting.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: I like the Deſcription you have given me of England extreamly, and envy the pleaſant Life your Ladies live. Here's a Health to their Husbands; I wiſh they cou'd teach ours their Complaiſance.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: We had rather teach their Wives, Madam, who have much more Docility: But here's to their Converſion.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: We! Why are you in the Number of marry'd Men?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I have a Breviat to act as one, Madam, in the Abſence of your Husband, if it is not your Fault. Come, my Angel, we ſhall be interrupted again.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Why? you have no more Friends to come down the Chimney, have you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: If you have, I waſh my Hands of him; no more Deliverance from me, I aſſure him. I hate to have a Scheme baulk'd that is ſo well laid.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No, no, Seniora Margaritta: What I apprehend is the Return of your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: He's ſafe for three Days, which time I expect you paſs with me. I have ſeveral Doubts to be reſolv'd, and as many Articles to make, e'er I give my ſelf entirely to your Power.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What Agreements are we to make, I wonder? This Intrigue will end very fooliſhly, I foreſee that. [Aſide.] All Secrets, I ſuppoſe. The next Room is more private, I fancy; there I'll do my Endeavour to ſolve your Scruples.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Margaritta, bring in the Wine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well thought on.
sp.l: The amorous Feaſt of Cupid ſoon wou'd cloy,
If Bacchus did not joyn the fainting Boy.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p:
And is it then true at laſt? Am I a Cuckold? Oh Vengeance! Vengeance! Oh Anthony, thou Guardian Saint of
Lisbon, give me Patience; let me have Chriſtian Charity upon their Souls, for I ſhall have no Mercy upon their Bodies. I have ſent for two Prieſts to take their Confeſſions, and then they die: Here I'll wait their Coming; ſhou'd I enter, my Eyes wou'd let looſe my Revenge too ſoon: 'Tis enough that I have them ſecure, and that my Ears have heard a Man's Voice with this vile Adultreſs.

l.hi: But ſince ſuch Pleaſure in his Arms ſhe proves,
Death ſhall join her unto the thing ſhe loves.

head.hi: SCENE changes to the Terriera de Paſſa.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: As I ſuſpected, he is here in this Houſe; thro' the Sovereign Power of Gold I have diſcover'd all; but for my Eaſe, wou'd I had been ignorant ſtill. Vice, thou uglieſt Picture of the Soul, by what Power doſt thou charm, and lull aſleep the Dictates of a Conſcience? And who can boaſt of Honour, that ſtarts not at the Breach of Vows? Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Methinks I never went ſo heavily of an Errand in my Life: I am ſorry for this Engliſhman, and heartily ſorry for my Miſtreſs; for, to give her her due, ſhe is the beſt-natur'd Woman to her Servants living: And, faith, I can't blame her for loving this Gentleman better than that old gouty, ptiſicky, crook-back'd, covetous Hunks my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Isah.
sp.p: Ha! this is the Servant which I brib'd. Of what Errand is he ſent? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What Saint ſhall I invoke, to ſave this wretched Pair? I know St. Anthony is engag'd on Don Perriera's Side—Let me ſee, there is ſome She-Saint that has been a Sinner this way her ſelf; if I cou'd think of her Name, ſhe'd be the fitteſt Perſon to do their Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Their Buſineſs! Oh, my boading Heart foretels ſome Miſchief. Lorenzo—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Ha! who's there?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis I, fear not: What is the Cauſe of your Complaint?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Oh! is it you, Senior? Oh, your Country-man's undone. My Maſter, pretending to go to St. Ubes for three Days, conceal'd himſelf in the Houſe unknown to every body, and has diſcover'd all. I'm ſent this Moment for two Monks from the Convent of Sante Vincente to confeſs the Criminals, and then you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Death! Oh Diſtraction! which, oh, which way, ye Powers, ſhall I ſave this perjur'd Man?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Ay, dear Sir, think, if it be poſſible.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh Charles! little doſt thou think how dear thy unlawful Joys are purchas'd; three Lives for a momentary Bliſs: For, in ſpight of all the Cauſe that thou haſt given me, thou'rt ſtill as dear as Virtue to my Soul, and Life without thee is not to be born. Oh, hear me Heav'n, that knows my chaſte Deſires, and pity the Diſtreſs that tears my Breaſt; inſtruct me how to ward this fatal Blow, and ſave a Man that may return to thee. Ha! methinks I feel the inſpiring Thought, and Hope begins to feed the Springs of Life—Lorenzo, firſt bring the Prieſts to me. If you perform this Buſineſs with Succeſs and Secrecy, I'll double twice this Sum.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: May I meet the Fate deſign'd for them, if I'm not faithful to you.

l.hi: If by this Plot I ſave this perjur'd Man,
I give the greateſt Proof of Love that Mortal can.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Iſabinda in a Ferriwig and Night-gown, and two Prieſts; a Sword lying upon the Table.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.p: PLead not for Adultery; wou'd you have us draw a Scandal on our Function?

sp.speaker: 2 Prieſt.
sp.p: All we can do is to ſet the Criminals right in their Journey to the other World, Son.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
Oh, 'tis a long Journey, Fathers; and who ſhall bring you word how they arrive? Tell me, even you who purchaſe
Heav'n daily by your Prayer, to ſell and canton out as you think fit, how wou'd you receive a Summons of this Nature? Wou'd ſudden Death appear a welcome Gueſt?

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.p: The Innocent can never fear to die. Had he, for whom you plead, liv'd free from Guilt, Death wou'd appear no formidable Enemy.

sp.speaker: 2 Prieſt.
sp.p: Suffer us to diſcharge our Office, or we muſt leave you. [Going.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh, my tortur'd Soul! if they go, Charles is loſt for ever. [Aſide.] He that treads this way treads upon his Death.
sp.stage: [Runs and catches up the Sword, draws, and gets between them and the Door.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.p: Ha! St. Vincent defend us.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not all the Saints your Calendar can boaſt ſhall ſave you, except you ſave my Brother; your Innocence can never fear to die—

And tho' your Souls will know no Pity here, when I've diſcharg'd 'em from thoſe heavy Carcaſſes, they may prove a Convoy to theſe Strangers. You who daily trade with Heav'n, muſt ſurely know the Road.

sp.speaker: 2 Prieſt
sp.p: Hold, hold—if we thought this Matter cou'd be done with Safety, and that it was Charity to ſave them—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: That it is Charity, let this demonſtrate—Here's 200 Moydres to be employ'd in charitable Uſes.
sp.l: Perhaps the Prayers of ſuch whom you relieve
May pull a Bleſſing from offended Heav'n,
And this poor guilty Pair may find Forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.p: This is a Youth of excellent Parts.

sp.speaker: 2 Prieſt.
sp.p: A Favourite of St. Vincent's, I warrant, he's ſo charitable. Well, Son, ſeeing you ſo well inclin'd, we do conſent, propoſe the way: Take care you do not expoſe us—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'll tell you my Deſign within, 'tis free from Hazard, or may the Puniſhment deſign'd for them be mine. I'll follow you, Fathers.

l.hi: O'er all Degrees of Men Gold bears a Sway,
Where all Entreaties fail, Gold finds the way;
Be thou propitious, Heav'n, and bleſs the Scheme I lay.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: What a curſed while this Raſcal ſtays; if he comes not inſtantly my Rage will get the better of my Reaſon, and I ſhall diſpatch the foul Adulterers without Confeſſion.

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo, and Iſabinda in Prieſts Habit, and one of the Prieſts with her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I have obey'd your Orders, Senior, here are the Prieſts.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: But very ſlowly, Hang-dog.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Peace be to you, Son.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: That's not your Buſineſs, Father; try if you can adminiſter Peace to my ſalacious Wife and her young Amouretta within there; but do you hear, Fathers? Diſpatch the Buſineſs of their Souls as ſpeedily as I will that of their Bodies: But if Heav'n has no more Mercy than I ſhall have, your Labours might have been ſpar'd.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Speak not ſo irreligiouſly—Which is the Room? Keep your diſtance.

sp.speaker: D. Per.
sp.p: Make haſte then, or I ſhall take your Work out of your Hands. Now let me conſult my inſtruments of Death, for I'll have no bounds in my Revenge. I'll, I'll, I'll, flea 'em alive.

head.hi: Scene draws and diſcovers Dona Perriera and Charles.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Is it the unreaſonableneſs of my Requeſt, or the ſmallneſs of your Reſpect, that cauſes this Heſitation, Senior? Sure if I give my ſelf intirely to your Arms, I may deſerve to be freed from the Embraces of a Wretch I hate. I'll not be chargeable to you in my Paſſage, I have Jewels of conſiderable Value to defray that Expence; I inſiſt upon a Promiſe, that you will convey me to England, and then I am yours.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why then to deal ingeniouſly, Madam, I am married in England, and ſhan't well know how to beſtow you there—But whilſt I am here, Child, I am thine—

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Ah! Maria mater, dic ora pro nobis, [Croſſing her ſelf.] Oh, we're undone, this hour is our laſt.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Laying his Hand on his Sword.] Ha! What are you?

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Our Habits ſhow what we are, and your Guilt what you have need of.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Prieſts! Nay, then our condition is worſe than I expected.
sp.stage: [Don Per. Runs and falls on her Knees.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Oh, confeſs me ſtreight, my Soul is taking flight already; I ſee a thouſand dire revengeful Fiends hovering o'er me, and watching all to catch it in the Air. Oh ſave it Father by your Holy Prayers, for in you only all my Comforts center.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Come Son, conſider the great Work you have to do, Death waits without, therefore examine your ſelf within.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Work muſt be all my own, Father, I have no occaſion for a Journey-man, ſo you may ſpare your Pains.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How, a Heretick! alas poor Soul, how much it troubles me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Pray good Father expreſs your trouble ſome where elſe, I have no Faith in your living Doctrine, and reſolve to have nothing to do with you in Death, therefore don't trouble me—Is there no way to eſcape, and muſt I die cowardly? No, that I will not, [Draws] the firſt that enters dies; I'll have Company at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A weak Defence, alas, ſhou'd I deſert him—Put up your Sword, in pity to your Ignorance, and in hopes of Converting you to the true Faith, I'll deliver you from this hazard.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But can you ſave her too?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How Son! Is this a time to dream of future Pleaſures?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'll give you mine Honour, Father, never to ſee her more; but as I am Partner in the Guilt, I wou'd not have the Puniſhment be only hers.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well, I'll endeavour to preſerve her too; obſerve my Orders well, turn your Face, here put on this Garment, my Brother there will conduct you to a place of ſafety, where I deſire you'll wait till I come; look not behind you, nor ſpeak as you paſs the Husband of that Lady.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This Prieſt is an honeſt Fellow, [Puts on the Cloaths.] nothing like the Habit of Sanctity to cover cloſe Deſigns, I ſhall obſerve your Directions moſt religiouſly, Father.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Come Son, your Hand—Madam, I leave you one to comfort your Diſtreſs.

head.hi: [Scene ſhuts, then draws and diſcovers Don Perreira Liſſening.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: How ſtill they are at Confeſſion, I fancy the Penance I ſhall enjoin them, will quicken their Voice. So,
So your parts are done then, Fathers? Now for mine.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Done! I'm afraid Son, you are not right in your Senſes, you have given us the trouble of coming to confeſs two Adulterers, you ſaid, but how you can make two Women ſuch; I leave to you, for there is no Male thing in the Room by my Prieſthood; take care you put no more Affronts upon our Cloth.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Women! I'm amaz'd! Women! Egad I'm raviſh'd, tranſported, nay, tranſlated methinks above the Stars; I'm, I'm, I'm, I'm, od I know not what I am, I'm ſo glad to find my ſelf no Cuckold—Ah, but how ſhall I look my Wife in the Face tho', for having blam'd her wrongfully? Ay, there's the Devil now—Pox take her Brother for inſtilling theſe Jealouſies into my Head, I fear ſhe will never forgive me—and indeed 'tis more than I deſerve—Oh, that ever I ſhould ſuſpect her Virtue.

head.hi: The Scene draws and diſcovers Dona Perriera on her Knees to Iſabinda.

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.p: Oh Madam, you have ſet Vice and Virtue in their proper Light, from whence I ſee the Deformity of one, and Beauty of the other; your generous Forgiveneſs is all I want, to raiſe my Soul above a ſecond fall. I have injur'd you, but—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No more of that; the good Inclination which you ſhow wipes out all faults with me, and your Perſeverance will give you as large a ſhare in my Breaſt, as if you never had offended. Riſe Madam, I hear the Door unlock, prepare your Husband according to my direction, and leave the reſt to me.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Ay, there they are—both Woman by St. Anthony—that ever I ſhould be ſuch a Dunce to think my ſelf a Cuckold—Which way ſhall I ſpeak to her now? Oh, my poor dear innocent Lamb is all in Tears, nay thou haſt cauſe to weep, that is the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What have I done, my Dear, that you ſhou'd expoſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: That thou haſt done nothing at all to merit it, is my grief—Nay do not weep, thou wilt break my Heart, indeed thou wilt; I wiſh with all my Soul thou hadſt Cuckolded me; I think in my Conſcience I cou'd forgive thee now.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: What Reparation can you ever make me, for the ſtain you have caſt upon my Fame, expos'd me to the Prieſts, cou'd you have found no other way?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I was to blame indeed, Wife; oh forgive me, [falls on his Knees.] or my Heart will burſt: Oh, oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nay, now, Madam, you muſt forgive him.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Ay do, dear Madam, intercede for me; I'll never riſe, except my dear virtuous Spouſe will ſay ſhe pardon me.

div.stage: Enter Don Lopez with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: What! Hangman like, are you asking Pardon e'er you diſpatch her? I'll lend you a helping hand, ſince you are not Maſter of your Reſolution.
sp.stage: [Don Per. riſes haſtily, and catches down a Blunderbuſs and cocks it at Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Zounds, put up your Sword, or by St. Anthony I'll ſhoot you through the Head.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Do you ſtart, Brother? Cou'd you inflict that on me which your own Courage ſtarts at? Cruel Man.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Brother ſhou'd rather reconcile, than blow the Coals of ſtrife; 'tis barbarous in Strangers, but much more ſo in thoſe ally'd to us by Blood: Revenge, tho' juſt, excludes Religion, and he that purſues it poiſons all his Morals, and impudently affronts that Power which gave him Breath to threaten.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p: Hie day, what Philoſopher have we here?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Out of my Lodgings, I ſay, without one queſtion more, and never ſet foot into them again, as you hope to keep your Guts in▪ I'll be plagu'd with no more of your Jealouſies, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Don Lop.
sp.p:
Fine! your Lodgings!—but hear me, Don, dare not for your Soul, ſay you match'd into my Family, or you Miſtreſs boaſt of any Blood of mine, as you value thoſe Eyes—for from
this day I hold you as a Baſtard, and may Perdition ſeize you both.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Was ever Man ſo plagu'd?—Come, dry thy Eyes, my Dear, and mind him not, I'm glad I'm rid of him—and if thou doſt but forgive me now, by this I'll ne'er offend again.
sp.stage: [Croſſes his Thumb and Finger, and kiſſes it.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Pray Wife, who is this Lady?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Heav'ns! what ſhall I ſay now? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Hold, Madam,—Let me intreat your Preſence, with your Lady's, in my Apartment, which is directly under this, and that you wou'd ſuſpend you Curioſity 'till that time.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: This is certainly an Angel in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: We'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's Mademoiſel Joneton to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Bring her up.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'll take my leave, and ſhall expect you with impatience.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: The deſire of knowing how to treat you as I ought, Madam, will give me Wings to follow you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: My Dear, I'm glad to ſee you—Oh Senior, are you there? Pray when do you intend to return to your Houſe? Will it never be finiſh'd? It is enough to Murder one to come up thus high—Poſitively I'm as much out of Breath as a Trumpeter. Ah peſt, it has given me a Colour like a Cook-Maid.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Thou art more impertinent than a Valet de Chambre. My Houſe will be finiſh'd next Week, Madam, and then 'tis to be hop'd theſe Diſorders which you complain of will ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Very probable they may—I am horridly chagreen'd to Day, my Dear, I have made twenty Viſits within this hour, and can meet with no Converſation to my Gout; the Vanity of the Men gives me the Spleen, and the Inſipidneſs of the Women makes me ſleepy—I came juſt now from my Lady Betty Trifle's, where I ſet the whole Room a yawning; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Impertinence—A Perſon of your polite Converſation, muſt not expect to be diverted every where: How does your Siſter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh my Siſter is this day dead, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: How! Dead?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: How! Dead?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Metaphorically ſpeaking, ſhe has enclos'd herſelf, where ſhe intends to mortifie with Hymns, and ſpiritual Songs, and has left me the whole World to range in.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: And I warrant you think that but a Garden.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If the Sea cou'd be drain'd, 'twou'd make a very pretty Park, Senior.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Humph! This is a Woman of a copious Fancy—Well my Dear, I'll go before you.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Not for the World—Madam, if you pleaſe, ſince you are upon the viſiting Pin, I'll introduce you to a new Acquaintance—I'd rather take her with me, than ſuffer him to go without me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all Satisfaction, I love new Acquaintance extremely, is it a Man?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: No; a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What has ſhe to recommend her?—But, no matter, I'll wait on you. The Devil take this Colonel, I can't get him out of my Head, I am half afraid I indure him more than I imagin'd. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: Madam, will you give me leave to wait on you down?

head.hi: The SCENE draws and diſcovers Charles ſolus, in Iſabinda's Appartment looking about him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What will be the iſſue of this Affair, Heav'n knows. To what end am I order'd to ſtay here, under the ſame Roof? And why is this Prieſt ſo long a coming? My Mind miſgives me, it was no Prieſt—But ſome Rival, jealous of her Favours, found the way to ſurpriſe us, and contrary to the Cuſtom of a Portugueſe, has Honour enough to diſpute it with me fairly; faith I wiſh that may be the worſt on't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Egad, here he is—Charles, I'm glad to find thee alive with all my Blood—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Devil! Ha! Colonel Ravelin there too? You ſurpriſe me? How did you find me?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: By Mar-plot's Direction, you know he's a very good finder, he aſſur'd me you wanted my Aſſiſtance—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah Charles, which got the better in the Duel, Ha? What Weapons did you fight with?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I can't tell what Engagement thou haſt been in, Charles, but by thy Looks, I fancy it has not pleas'd thee.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I have run ſome hazard ſince I ſaw you, Colonel, but if I had caught you dogging me, I'd a hamſtring'd you, Raſcal—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Very fine—See what a Man gets for his good will now—But if I had not thought you in danger of Hamſtringing, and Heartſtringing too; the Devil a ſtep wou'd I a fetch'd. I'm ſure the old Cuckold frighted me out of my Wits with his threats, and the Colonel here has almoſt broke my Bones, and all for you—And thus you reward me—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The old Cuckold! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, let the Colonel tell you what I mean, for my part I'll have nothing to do with you as long as I live again—Bleſs me, what do I ſee? The very old Dog that ſwore by Fire, Blood and Brimſtone, he wou'd ſend you to the Devil—Oh Lord, oh Lord, draw Gentlemen, draw, put your ſelf upon your Guard, Charles, oh dear Colonel ſtand by him; ods life I tremble ſo, I cannot get my Sword out for my Blood—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha! What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Get you behind me, you timerous Puppy.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: What do you mean, Gentlemen, to murder me?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I mean that you ſhan't murder me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: You, Sir? why I don't know you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not know him, Sir, what a confounded lying old Thief you are, I'll take my Oath I heard you and that bloody-minded Spaniard, threaten what you'd do to this Gentleman, if you catch'd him in your Houſe; egad Charles, knock him down.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Sweep-chimney, are you here? St. Anthony defend me, what Ambuſcade am I tumbled into? This was certainly my Wife's Gallant, and has impos'd upon the Prieſts, as well as me, in Petticoats, and now has trapan'd me here to murder me—Help, Murder, Treaſon, Murder, help—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Taking him by the Collar.] Ceaſe your bawling, old Lucifer, or expect no Mercy.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Confeſs your deſign, and produce your villainous Gang, and they ſhall have Satisfaction, equal to their Merits.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Gang? By St. Anthony, I have no Gang; I came hither to wait on the Lady who belongs to this Appartment, but little thought of meeting with my damnable virtuous Wife's Gallant. I ſuppoſe I am decoy'd hither to have my Throat cut, therefore come on both of you, old as I am, I yet can ſtand a Puſh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, oh, Murder, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I wiſh I had known you in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, this muſt be Don Perriera; but what does he mean by Petticoats? Hold, Sir—What is the Lady's Name of this Appartment?

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I know not, it was to be inform'd of that I came, but I ſuppoſe you are the Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: This ſhallow-brain'd Whelp has made a damn'd blunder here—This is a very odd Riddle, Sir, pray—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah! a Ghoſt, a Ghoſt, a Ghoſt—

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: St. Anthony defend me, a Ghoſt? where?
sp.stage: Enter Iſabinda, Dona Perriera, Mademoiſel and Margaritta.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, is it you? This is the Lady I came to wait on, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha! She here!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: That Lady, in the Habit of a Prieſt, delivered you—Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Know her! Yes—Delivered by my Wife—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: The Colonel here too? I'm not diſpleas'd with this Viſit. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: My Miſtreſs—a pretty kind of a Rencounter.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh let me fly into thy Arms, my Iſabinda, my charming Love, thou holdeſt more Virtues in thy Breaſt, than thy whole 〈◊〉 b •• ſt▪ Can'ſt thou forgive me, Iſabinda?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: As freely as thou can'ſt ask it; but huſh, we ſhall be obſerv'd; let not the Company know this is our firſt meeting. I was loath to truſt the Writings with Strangers, ſo brought them my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Thou are all Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I thought I heard Murder cry out as I enter'd, Senior.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Why truly, Madam, if you had not come as you did, I was in danger of my Life here.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: 'Twas only a Miſtake, my Dear. I ask your Pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Pardon, Sir? This is a very odd miſtake, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Egad, and ſo it is; a Pox of my Zeal—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I hope all Miſtakes will be clear'd, Sir, I know you loved my Father, Sir, Jealous Traffick; and for his ſake, I hope you'll know my Husband.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: What, my old Friend? Yes faith will I, Sir, I am yours, but I muſt kiſs your Wife. My Dear, why did not you tell me who ſhe was before?

sp.speaker: Dona Per.
sp.p: A good Reaſon, becauſe I did not know. [Aſide.] You ſaw ſhe forbad me, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now you are all acquainted, I'll tell you how I came to miſtake this Matter: I did not know this was a Houſe of Lodgings, nor that my Friend had remov'd hither, till I found him out by Accident, upon my Honour, Senior—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Rogue will ſtumble out an Excuſe.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Honour! Pray, Sir, upon your Honour tell me how you got out of my Room?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: For your Soul, no ſqueaking— [Aſide to Mar-plot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no; never fear me. Egad, what ſhall I ſay now? Why, Sir, you muſt know I am a Chimiſt, and have found out a Secret that will open and ſhut all Locks whatever; that help'd me out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? Pray will you communicate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not for your whole Eſtate, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: I'll have this Fellow ſent out of Town, for by the help of this Secret he'll Cuckold all the Men in Lisbon.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what a Lie has he lit of—Colonel, won't the Lady capitulate upon Honourable Terms?

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: She deſires two days Conſideration, a great while for a Man to faſt, that is almoſt ſtarv'd already.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, to ſhew you I am good-natur'd, I'll put it to Arbitration.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay, then Madam, we ſhall all give it againſt you.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: What's here, a Wedding on foot? Prithee let's have it juſt now, to reconcile all Differences, and tho' I have not danc'd theſe forty Years, will take a turn among you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So! I'll be hang'd if this is not Mademoiſel Flutter now. Pox of theſe Matrimonial Intreagues—but Egad we will have Dancing—I'm reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, the Cannon of Conſtancy is a heavy Carriage, and if I ſhou'd ſummon my Senſes to a Council of War, and make Reaſon Judge-Advocate, 'tis odds but I raiſe the Siege.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, if I ſurrender Priſoner of War, remember I expect to be generouſly us'd.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: You ſhall have no cauſe to complain.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We wiſh you Joy, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Don Per.
sp.p: Now for a Dance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I have brought the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Come, Colonel, Marriage is the only happy
State, when Virtue is the Guide.
Had but all Women Iſabinda's Mind,
So Conſtant, Prudent, Virtuous, and ſo kind,
What Joys ſo great as Wedlock cou'd we find?
No more ſhou'd we unlawful Love purſue,
But think our Wives for ever young and new,
And learn from them the Art of being true.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: In vain we ſtrive by haughty ways to prove
Our chaſt Affections, and our duteous Love.
To ſmooth the Husband's rugged Storms of Life,
Is the deſign and buſineſs of a Wife;
Still all his Faults with Patience to behold,
And not for ev'ry Trifle rant, and ſcold:
Men from Example, more than Precept, learn,
And modeſt Carriage ſtill has power to Charm.
After my Method, wou'd all Wives but move,
They'd ſoon regain, and keep their Husbands Love:
Our kind Indulgence wou'd their Vice o'ercome,
And with our Meekneſs ſtrike their Paſſions dumb.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THE Play concluded, I'm at laſt ſet free,
Reſume my ſelf, and now am Cap-a-pee,
A free-born Nymph of Engliſh Liberty.
I ſweat t' have been a Wife but three bare Hours;
What is't to be one then for Life, ye Powers,
Where Husbands too are ten times worſe than ours?
The ſlighteſt Trip with them demands our Blood;
But venial Frailties here are better underſtood.
Your Don Cornuted is a Monſter there,
But thank our Stars, the Fate's no Wonder here.
The Monſter ceaſes, where the Caſe is common,
And watch your Eyes out, you muſt truſt the Woman.
In vain her Perſon with Reſtraint you load,
When Spite of Walls her willing Mind's abroad.
A bleſſed Life indeed! where churliſh Fear
Attends the Thing your Appetites cou'd ſpare.
Is there on Earth, a Wretch, a greater Jeſt,
Than the pale Lover, ſtarv'd for Beauty's Feaſt,
That begs, in pity of his famiſh'd Senſe, a Taſte?
Proteſt his Appetite ſhall laſt for Ages,

Incurable his Pain, and laugh'd at in Diſtreſs,
He ſnarling cries, Conſume my Happineſs.
Oh, tireſome Plenty! O intollerable Bliſs!
Oh the loſt Joys of freeborn Wretchedneſs!
Like Dog in Manger, thus he ſnarles and bites,
And curſes what another's Taſte delights.
While ſuch Examples 'fore my Eyes I ſee,
Guard me, ye Powers, from Loſs of Liberty.
'Tis ſtrange, you Britains, whom no Force can humble,
Shou'd court thoſe Chains, at which you're ſure to grumble:
But ſince, alas! 'tis fatal to the Age,
I'll ev'n maintain my Poſt upon the Stage;
Which (for at once I'd all Mens Hope prevent)
I'll never leave, tho' tempted with a Settlement.
